part.name: P1
part.heading: General Rules for the Government of Prisons

section.name: s1
section.heading: Citation
section.content: These rules may be cited as the Prison Rules.

section.name: s1A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In these rules, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: barrister (大律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159); (L.N. 174 of 2025)
Medical Officer (醫生) means a medical officer appointed under section 3 of the Ordinance;
solicitor (律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159); (L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a member of the Executive Council;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a member of the Legislative Council;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a visiting justice;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: The Ombudsman appointed under section 3 of The Ombudsman Ordinance (Cap. 397); or

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the Commissioner of the Independent Commission Against Corruption; (L.N. 275 of 1997; 1 of 2003 s. 3)

section.def: visiting justice (巡獄太平紳士) means a justice of the peace for the time being appointed by the Chief Executive under section 23 of the Ordinance. (L.N. 275 of 1997; 15 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application of rules
section.content: The rules in this Part shall apply to all classes of prisoners except in so far as they may be inconsistent with the rules made to govern any particular class or classes of prisoners.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Sleeping accommodation
section.content: No sleeping accommodation for prisoners shall be used unless it is certified by the Commissioner to be of such a size, and to be lighted, ventilated and fitted in such a manner, as is requisite for health, and when such accommodation is locked it shall be furnished with the means of enabling prisoners to communicate at any time with an officer of the prison. If the certificate of any cell, room, dormitory or ward so used is cancelled, that accommodation shall not be used for sleeping unless it is again certified. The certificate shall specify the maximum number of prisoners to be accommodated at any one time in such a cell, room, dormitory or ward and the number so specified shall not be exceeded without the authority of the Commissioner.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Beds
section.content: Every prisoner shall be provided with a separate bed.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Hospital
section.content: In every institution to which a prisoner may be allocated under section 9(a) of the Ordinance a hospital or proper place for the reception of sick prisoners shall be provided.

section.name: s5A
section.heading: Restriction on entry of cell of member of opposite sex
section.content: No officer of the Correctional Services Department or other person employed in a prison shall enter a cell or dormitory allocated to a prisoner of the opposite sex unless accompanied by another officer or other person employed in the prison who is of the same sex as the prisoner to whom the cell or dormitory is allocated.

subsection.content: In a prison for both men and women the whole of the premises allocated to women shall be entirely separate. (L.N. 353 of 1981)
The keys of the premises allocated to women shall be under the control of female officers. (31 of 1983 s. 8)

section.name: s7
section.heading: Female prisoners
section.content: Female prisoners shall in all cases be attended by female officers. A male officer shall not enter a prison or part of a prison appropriated for the use of female prisoners except on duty and in the company of a female officer.

subsection.content: Where the Superintendent is satisfied that circumstances exist that warrant the provision of a diet that differs from the normal prison diet to a prisoner, he may direct that the prisoner be fed a different diet.

A prisoner who considers he should be provided with a diet that differs from the normal prison diet may appeal to the Commissioner against a decision of the Superintendent not to provide him with that different diet.

If a prisoner is not satisfied with a decision of the Commissioner on an appeal under subrule (2), he may further appeal to the Secretary for Security whose decision shall be final. (L.N. 95 of 1993; L.N. 150 of 2014)

Every prisoner shall be searched on admission and at such times subsequently as the Superintendent or other officer in charge may direct, and all articles for the possession of which no authority has been given shall be taken from him.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Medical Officer, or a Chief Officer, Principal Officer, Officer or Nurse, authorized by the Medical Officer, may, for the purpose of subrule (1), search the rectum, nostrils, ears and any other external orifice of a prisoner. (L.N. 2 of 1974; L.N. 150 of 2014)
The searching of a prisoner shall be conducted with due regard to decency and self-respect, and in as seemly a manner as is consistent with the necessity of discovering any concealed articles.

No prisoner shall be stripped and searched in the sight of another prisoner unless a senior officer considers it necessary in the interests of the security of a prison or the safety of any person. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

section.name: s10
section.heading: Provisions as to female prisoners
section.content: No prisoner shall be searched other than by an officer of the same sex. In other respects the same course shall be pursued in reference to the admission or discharge of a female prisoner as in the case of a male prisoner.

subsection.content: Money found on a prisoner committed for non-payment of a fine shall, unless a magistrate otherwise directs in writing on the warrant of commitment, be applied towards the fine adjudged to be paid, provided that the prisoner shall be allowed to keep $10 and any lesser sum which does not represent a day’s imprisonment. (L.N. 2 of 1974)

Subject to the provisions of subrule (1), all money, clothing and other effects belonging to a prisoner which he is not allowed to retain, shall be placed in the custody of the Superintendent, who shall cause an inventory thereof to be kept. Such inventory shall be signed by the prisoner concerned certifying its correctness. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s12
section.heading: Record of measurements and other particulars

subsection.content: The name, age, height, weight, particular marks and such other measurements and particulars as may be required in regard to a prisoner shall upon his admission and from time to time be recorded. (L.N. 353 of 1981)
Any physical or mental disability from which a prisoner may be suffering at the time of his admission shall be recorded. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

The religion, if any, of a prisoner shall be recorded at the time of his admission and he shall be treated during his term of imprisonment as being of any religion so recorded unless the Superintendent is satisfied that the prisoner is an adherent of another religion or has ceased to adhere to any religion.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Photographing of prisoner
section.content: Every prisoner may be photographed on reception and subsequently, but no copy of the photograph shall be given to any person unless he is officially authorized to receive it.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Medical examination on admission
section.leadIn: Every prisoner shall, as soon as possible after his admission, be separately examined by the Medical Officer, who shall record the state of health of the prisoner, and such other particulars as he may deem necessary:
section.proviso: Provided that when a prisoner is admitted too late to be examined on the same day he shall be examined as soon as possible on the next day, and in any case within 24 hours of admission.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Bath
section.content: Every prisoner shall take a bath on reception, unless the Superintendent or Medical Officer otherwise directs.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Disease or vermin
section.content: If any prisoner is found to have any infectious or contagious disease or to be infested with vermin, a report thereof shall be made forthwith to the Medical Officer under whose direction steps shall be taken to treat the condition and to prevent its transmission to other prisoners.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may grant leave of absence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: not exceeding 5 days at any one time to any prisoner who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has been sentenced to not less than 4 years’ imprisonment;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is within 6 months of the earliest date of release; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: has no deportation order made against him; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not exceeding 24 hours at any one time, to any other prisoner.

subsection.content: Leave of absence granted under subrule (1) shall be subject to such conditions and restrictions relating to custody and escort as the Commissioner may determine. (L.N. 150 of 2014)
Every prisoner shall as short a time as is practicable before discharge, or removal to another prison, be examined by the Medical Officer.
A prisoner shall not be removed to another prison unless the Medical Officer certifies that he is fit for removal.

A prisoner due for discharge who is suffering from an acute or dangerous illness shall, unless he refuses to stay, not be sent out of prison until in the opinion of the Medical Officer it is safe to send him out.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Custody of prisoner outside prison
section.content: Every prisoner for whose production at any place an order is issued shall, while outside the prison, be kept in the custody of the officers directed to convey him to that place.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Protection from public view
section.content: When prisoners are being removed to or from prison, they shall be exposed to public view as little as possible, and proper safeguards shall be adopted to protect them from insult or curiosity.

subsection.content: The child of a female prisoner may be received into prison with its mother and kept during the normal period of lactation and any child so admitted shall not be taken from its mother until the Medical Officer certifies that it is in a fit condition to be removed.

When any child received into prison under subrule (1) is over the age of 9 months or attains that age while in prison the Medical Officer shall report to the Commissioner whether, in his opinion, it is necessary or desirable that such child should be retained in prison. The Commissioner may commit such child to the care of such relative of the child as may be willing and able to undertake such care and who may, in his opinion, be a fit and proper person to undertake such care. If the Commissioner is unable to find any relative of the child to whose care such child may properly be entrusted, then he may commit such child to the care of any person or institution approved by the Chief Executive. (15 of 1999 s. 3; L.N. 150 of 2014)

Notwithstanding the provisions of subrules (1) and (2) the Commissioner may permit any child to remain in the prison until the mother has completed her sentence or such child has attained the age of 3 years whichever is the earlier. (L.N. 150 of 2014)
Any child retained in prison may be supplied with clothing at the public expense.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Payment of portion of fine to obtain remission
section.content: Any payment made in part satisfaction of the sum adjudged to be paid by a prisoner and of any charges for which he is liable, in order to obtain the remission of a part of his imprisonment, as provided by section 114 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) and section 37 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) shall be made only on a week-day between the hours of 9 and 12 in the morning and 2 and 4 in the afternoon.

section.name: s22A
section.heading: Discharge on general holiday
section.content: A prisoner due for discharge on a general holiday shall be discharged on the day next preceding that day which is not a general holiday.

subsection.content: No prisoner shall without authority have in his possession any article, and any such article found in his possession shall be confiscated by the Superintendent.

No person shall without authority convey or throw into, or deposit in, a prison, or convey or throw out of a prison, or convey to any prisoner, or deposit with a view to its coming into the possession of any prisoner, any money, clothing, food, drink, tobacco, letter, paper, book, tool or other article whatsoever. Any article so conveyed, thrown or deposited without authority may be confiscated by the Superintendent.
All persons and vehicles entering or leaving a prison may be examined and searched.

subsection.leadIn: A person suspected—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of bringing without authority any article into a prison; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: of carrying out without authority—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any article; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any property belonging to a prison; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: while in a prison of being—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in possession without authority of any article; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in improper possession of any property belonging to a prison,

subsection.continued: shall be stopped and immediate notice thereof shall be given to the Superintendent, who may order that he shall be examined and searched.

subsection.content: The Superintendent may refuse admission to a prison of a person who is unwilling to be examined and searched.
The Superintendent may direct the removal from a prison of a person who while in a prison is unwilling to be examined and searched or whose conduct is improper.
No person shall be searched under this rule other than by an officer of the same sex. (L.N. 2 of 1974)

No prisoner shall be given or allowed to have any intoxicating liquor except in pursuance of a written order of the Medical Officer specifying the quantity to be given and the name of the prisoner for whose use it is intended.
No prisoner shall be allowed to smoke or to have in his possession any tobacco except in accordance with such order as may be given by the Commissioner.
The Superintendent must provide every prisoner with a uniform that meets a scale imposed by the Commissioner.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the matters that the Commissioner may take into consideration in imposing the scale, the Commissioner must impose the scale for the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensuring the safety, comfort, health and hygiene of prisoners;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: safeguarding prisoners’ privacy;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ensuring that prisoners are decently dressed;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ensuring that prisoners are suitably dressed during the course of work or other activities in which they would likely be engaged; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: maintaining the security, good order and discipline of the prison.

subsection.content: A prisoner must not wear any clothes other than the uniform unless with the approval of the Superintendent given in special circumstances.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Return of prisoner’s clothing on discharge
section.content: On the discharge of a prisoner, his own clothes shall be returned to him unless it has been found necessary to destroy or otherwise dispose of them, in which case he shall be provided with proper clothing.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Blankets
section.leadIn: Every prisoner shall be provided with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: blankets adequate for warmth and health in accordance with a scale approved by the Commissioner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: additional blankets in special circumstances on the recommendation of the Medical Officer.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Prohibition of unauthorized clothing, blankets, etc.
section.content: A prisoner shall not, except with the authority of the Commissioner in special circumstances, or in pursuance of special rules, have in his possession any clothing, blankets or necessaries otherwise than in accordance with the scales approved by the Commissioner.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Possession of food
section.leadIn: No prisoner shall receive or have in his possession any food otherwise than in accordance with the dietary scales approved by the Chief Executive except— (15 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in special circumstances with the permission of the Commissioner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the recommendation of the Medical Officer if a variation of diet is desirable on medical grounds for any individual prisoner.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Quantity of food
section.content: Except on the written recommendation of the Medical Officer in the case of a prisoner who persistently wastes his food or on medical grounds by direction of the Medical Officer no prisoner shall have less food than is provided in the normal prison diet.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Complaints as to food supplied
section.content: Every prisoner who has any complaint to make regarding the food furnished to him, or who wishes his food to be weighed or measured in order to ascertain whether he is supplied with the prescribed quantity, shall make his complaint immediately his food is handed to him, and it shall be weighed or measured in his presence and in that of the officer deputed for that purpose.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Obedience to directions as to cleanliness
section.content: Every prisoner shall obey such directions as regards washing, bathing, shaving and hair cutting as may from time to time be prescribed.

section.name: s34A
section.heading: Prisoner’s urine for examination
section.content: The Medical Officer, or a Chief Officer, Principal Officer or Nurse, authorized by the Medical Officer, may require a prisoner to submit, within a reasonable period, a specimen of his urine for examination and analysis.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Duty to keep cells, rooms or dormitories, utensils, etc., clean
section.content: Every prisoner shall keep his cell, room or dormitory, his utensils, books, and other articles issued for his use, and his clothing and bedding, clean and neatly arranged, as may be ordered.

subsection.content: Every prisoner unless excused by the Medical Officer on medical grounds shall take such exercise as may be ordered.

Whenever in the opinion of the Superintendent it is desirable either in the interests of a prisoner or in the interests of prison discipline, that a prisoner should perform his labour in a cell, the Superintendent may order him to do so; and in such case he shall perform such labour as can be suitably performed in a cell.

The Superintendent shall report to the Commissioner every order given under the provisions of subrule (2), and at the expiry of each calendar month’s confinement the Commissioner shall review such order and, if he considers it desirable, direct that the prisoner returns to work in association. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s38
section.heading: General requirement of work
section.leadIn: Every prisoner shall be required to engage in useful work for not more than 10 hours a day, of which so far as practicable at least 8 hours shall be spent in associated or other work outside the cells, rooms, dormitories or wards:
section.proviso: Provided that the Medical Officer may excuse a prisoner from work on medical grounds, and no prisoner shall be set to any work unless he has been certified as fit for that type of work by the Medical Officer.

subsection.content: A prisoner who is under 21 years of age may be required to attend educational classes.
For the purpose of rule 38, the time spent by a prisoner in educational classes shall be counted as time engaged in useful work.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Payment
section.content: A prisoner who works and a prisoner who, through no fault of his own, is unable to work, may receive payment in accordance with rates, in each case, approved by the Commissioner.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Prohibition of employment of prisoner in unauthorized work

subsection.content: A prisoner shall not be employed on any work not authorized by the Commissioner nor shall he be employed in any disciplinary capacity.
A prisoner shall not be employed in any capacity that is a position within the establishment of a department or bureau of the Civil Service. (L.N. 353 of 1981; 15 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s41
section.heading: Jewish prisoners
section.content: Jewish prisoners shall not be compelled to work on Saturdays if they claim exemption. They may observe such festival days as may be allowed by the Commissioner.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Hours of labour
section.content: The hours of labour shall not be less than 6 nor more than 10 daily, exclusive of meals.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Holidays
section.content: No work shall be done beyond what is strictly necessary on Sunday, Christmas Day, Good Friday and Chinese New Year’s day.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Mohammedan prisoners
section.content: Mohammedan prisoners shall be allowed to observe the fast of Ramadan and during the fast shall be required to labour at such reduced task as the Medical Officer considers proper.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Employment of prisoners on public works
section.text: Subject to the approval of the Chief Executive prisoners may be employed on works of a public nature.

subsection.content: Subject to these rules, a prisoner may write and send as many letters as he wishes to any person.

A prisoner shall be furnished with materials and postage sufficient to write and send one letter per week not exceeding 4 pages of A-4 paper in length at public expense, and shall, where the prisoner so requests, be furnished with materials and postage for additional letters subject to the payment of the cost thereof from the prisoner’s earnings.

paragraph.name: a

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the Superintendent is satisfied that the prisoner—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: has a genuine need to write and send additional letters; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: does not have sufficient earnings to pay the cost thereof; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the prisoner is a member of a class of prisoners encouraged to build links with their families.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraph (a)(ii), a person shall be regarded as a member of a class of prisoners encouraged to build links with their families if— (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: this rule applies to him as if he were a prisoner by virtue of—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: section 10 of the Detention Centres Ordinance (Cap. 239);

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: section 9 of the Drug Addiction Treatment Centres Ordinance (Cap. 244); or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: section 8 of the Training Centres Ordinance (Cap. 280); or
he is a prisoner under 21 years of age.

subsection.content: Despite subrule (2), if a prisoner requests to write and send a letter to a specified person, the Superintendent must permit the prisoner to write and send the letter at public expense. (L.N. 174 of 2025)
Subject to these rules, a prisoner may receive any number of letters from any person.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: A prisoner is not permitted to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: send a letter to, or receive a letter from, another prisoner, unless he has obtained the prior approval of the Superintendent;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: send a letter to, or receive a letter from, a person where the Superintendent has reasonable grounds to believe that the letter will bring about one or more of the effects mentioned in subrule (6A);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: send a letter to a person where that person has advised the Superintendent that he does not wish to receive any letter from that prisoner.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: The Superintendent shall not withhold approval for the purposes of paragraph (a)(i) in respect of any letter unless— (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Superintendent, or an officer of the Correctional Services Department designated by the Superintendent for the purposes of this rule, has not been given a reasonable opportunity to read the letter for the purposes of that paragraph; or (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Superintendent has reasonable grounds to believe that the letter will bring about one or more of the effects mentioned in subrule (6A).

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.leadIn: The effects are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being contrary to the interests of national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: tending to cause the commission of any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: being detrimental to the rehabilitation of any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posing a threat to any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: posing a threat to the security, good order and discipline of the prison. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Subject to paragraph (b), where a prisoner has committed any of the offences enumerated in rule 61, the Superintendent may, for a period not exceeding 3 months, prohibit the prisoner from writing and sending more than one letter per week, in addition to any punishment which may be awarded in respect of the prisoner under rule 63 for the offence.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraph (a), where any letter from a prisoner in respect of whom a prohibition under that paragraph is in force is— (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a letter to a specified person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a letter to a barrister or solicitor which is a bona fide communication for the purpose of seeking legal advice,

paragraph.continued: then, in so far as the prohibition is concerned, the letter shall not be regarded as a letter within the meaning of that paragraph. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s47A
section.heading: Screening of prisoners’ outgoing and incoming letters

def.name: MaximumSecurityPrison
def.leadIn: In this rule, maximum security prison (高度設防監獄) means a prison which is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: equipped with such security measures as are suitable in the opinion of the Commissioner for the admission of prisoners representing great security risks in terms of the likelihood of their attempting to escape and the danger to the public if an escape succeeds; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specified as a maximum security prison in a notice displayed in a conspicuous position in all prisons.

subsection.content: All letters to or from a prisoner in any prison may be opened or searched for examining whether there is any article that will bring about one or more of the effects mentioned in subrule (9). (L.N. 174 of 2025)
All letters to or from a prisoner in a maximum security prison may, apart from being searched under subrule (2), be read. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subsection.leadIn: A letter to or from a prisoner in any prison other than a maximum security prison may, apart from being searched under subrule (2), be read where the Superintendent, or an officer of the Correctional Services Department designated by the Superintendent for the purposes of this rule, has reasonable grounds to believe that— (L.N. 150 of 2014; L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the reading will assist in one or more of the following—

subparagraph.content: safeguarding national security;
preventing or detecting any criminal offence;
rehabilitating any prisoner;
safeguarding any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the letter is likely to contain evidence of an act that would jeopardise the health or safety of any person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the letter is to the prisoner from, or from the prisoner to, any other prisoner without the prior approval of the Superintendent under rule 47(6)(a)(i); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the reading would be in the best interests of the prisoner.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: Where a letter is read under subrule (3) or (4) by the Superintendent, or an officer of the Correctional Services Department designated by the Superintendent for the purposes of this rule, and the letter contains one or more of the matters mentioned in subrule (5), the Superintendent or the officer may stop the letter. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: The matters are— (L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any matter the mailing of which is prohibited by law;

paragraph.name: b
c
e
paragraph.content: threats, extortion, obscenity or gratuitous profanity;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any message expressed in code;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any material that is intended for publication or for broadcast by radio or television (or which, if sent, is likely to be published or broadcast) and that refers to individual prisoners or to members of the staff of the Correctional Services Department in such a way that they may be identified;

paragraph.name: h

paragraph.content: any material that the Superintendent or an officer of the Correctional Services Department mentioned in subrule (4A) has reasonable grounds to believe that it will bring about one or more of the effects mentioned in subrule (9). (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.content: Where a letter is searched under subrule (2) or read under subrule (3) or (4) and the letter exceeds 4 pages of A-4 paper in length, the Superintendent, or an officer of the Correctional Services Department designated by the Superintendent for the purposes of this rule, may stop the letter. (L.N. 150 of 2014; L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: Where a letter is stopped under subrule (4A) or (6)— (L.N. 150 of 2014; L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in case the letter is from a prisoner—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: inform, orally or in writing, the prisoner of the reason for the letter being so stopped; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: give the prisoner a reasonable opportunity to rewrite the letter; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: if, after a reasonable opportunity to rewrite the letter has been given to the prisoner under subparagraph (i)(B), the prisoner does not rewrite the letter, or the rewritten letter still contains any matter referred to in subrule (5) or still exceeds 4 pages of A-4 paper in length, as the case may be, the Superintendent may— (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: withhold the letter; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: after informing the prisoner that he is doing so, file it in the prisoner’s penal record;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in case the letter is to a prisoner, the Superintendent— (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must inform, orally or in writing, the prisoner of the reason for the letter being so stopped; and (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: return the letter to the sender;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: retain the letter; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: destroy the letter. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: The effects are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being contrary to the interests of national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: tending to cause the commission of any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: being detrimental to the rehabilitation of any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posing a threat to any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: posing a threat to the security, good order and discipline of the prison. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

section.name: s47B
section.heading: Letters to or from prisoner’s barrister or solicitor

subsection.content: Despite rule 47A but subject to this rule and rule 52C, where it appears to an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Principal Officer that any letter is to a prisoner from, or from a prisoner to, a barrister or solicitor, the letter must not be opened or searched under rule 47A(2), except in the presence of the prisoner or where the prisoner indicates that he or she does not wish to be present.

Despite rule 47A but subject to subrule (3) and rule 52C, where it appears to an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Principal Officer that any letter is to a prisoner from, or from a prisoner to, a barrister or solicitor, the letter must not be read under rule 47A(3) or (4) unless the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that the letter is not a bona fide communication for the purpose of seeking or giving legal advice. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

subsection.leadIn: Where pursuant to or purportedly pursuant to subrule (2) a letter is read under rule 47A(3) or (4)— (L.N. 150 of 2014)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it shall only be read by an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Principal Officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the officer shall only read it to the extent necessary to determine whether it is a bona fide communication for the purpose of seeking or giving legal advice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if it is such a bona fide communication, the officer shall not divulge its contents to any person.

section.name: s47C
section.heading: Letters to or from specified person
section.leadIn: Despite rules 47A and 52C, where it appears to an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Principal Officer that any letter is to a prisoner from, or from a prisoner to, a specified person, the letter— (L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must neither be opened or searched under rule 47A(2), nor be opened under rule 52C(2)(c), except in the presence of the prisoner or where the prisoner indicates that he or she does not wish to be present; and (L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not be read under rule 47A(3) or (4) or 52C(2)(c). (L.N. 174 of 2025)

section.name: s47D
section.heading: Supplementary provisions for rules 47A, 47B and 47C
section.content: For the purposes of rules 47A, 47B and 47C, if a prisoner sends a letter to a person (original recipient), but the letter is returned by the post office because it is undeliverable for any reason, the letter is to be treated as a letter from the original recipient to the prisoner.

subsection.content: Subject to these rules, a prisoner must not receive any visit from any person who has not been authorized under subrule (2).
The Commissioner may authorize any person whom the Commissioner considers appropriate for the purposes of subrule (1).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the restrictions and conditions mentioned in subrule (4), a prisoner may receive a visit from any person so long as the purpose of the visit is, with a view to facilitating the prisoner’s rehabilitation or reintegration into society—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enabling the prisoner to maintain connections with his or her family or with society; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing moral support or material support to the prisoner.

subsection.leadIn: The restrictions and conditions are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prisoner must consent to receiving the visit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the visit must not be made otherwise than on the date and at the time specified by the Superintendent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: every prisoner must not receive the visit more than twice per month;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the visit must be made by not more than 3 visitors on each occasion;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the visit is limited to 30 minutes on each occasion;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: at least 1 officer of the Correctional Services Department must be present during the visit; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a person who wishes to make the visit must produce the person’s proof of identity (as defined by section 17B(1) of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115)) in advance to an officer of the Correctional Services Department for inspection, and provide the person’s name, address, the relationship to the prisoner, and other personal data that the Superintendent reasonably considers to be necessary for the purposes of this rule, to the officer for record purposes.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subrule (3), the Superintendent may, for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subrule (6)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the visit—

subparagraph.content: vary one or more of the restrictions or conditions mentioned in subrule (4); or
impose any other restrictions or conditions; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prohibit the visit.

subsection.leadIn: The purposes are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safeguarding national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: preventing or detecting any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: rehabilitating any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: safeguarding any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: maintaining the security, good order and discipline of the prison.

subsection.content: If a prisoner is entitled to receive a visit under this rule, the prisoner may write a letter instead of receiving the visit, and may, for this purpose, make an application to the Superintendent for the furnishing of the materials and postage under rule 47(2) (at public expense) for writing the letter, regardless of whether the prisoner has already been furnished with the materials and postage in the week concerned such that no further furnishing of them would have been made under that rule in that week.
Any police officer may visit prisoners for the purpose of identification parades, on production of an order from the proper police or judicial authority. (L.N. 353 of 1981)
Any police officer may visit prisoners for the purpose of inquiring into reported or reasonably suspected offences. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

section.name: s50
section.heading: Visits by officers of the Court
section.content: Officers of the Court, with competent warrants or orders for serving writs or other legal process on persons within the prison, shall be admitted into the prison for that purpose.

subsection.leadIn: Reasonable facilities must be allowed for the barrister or solicitor of a prisoner, or a person who assists the barrister or solicitor’s performance of his or her functions as a barrister or solicitor—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to visit the prisoner for providing legal advice to the prisoner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to visit the prisoner for any legal proceedings relating to the prisoner (or such legal proceedings that are contemplated),

subsection.continued: in the sight but not in the hearing of an officer of the Correctional Services Department. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.content: This rule is subject to rule 52A. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

section.name: s52A
section.heading: Prisoners may be restricted from connecting with particular legal representatives in certain circumstances

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a prisoner requests to connect with a particular legal representative or particular legal representatives;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a particular legal representative or particular legal representatives request to connect with a prisoner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a particular legal representative or particular legal representatives are connecting with a prisoner.

subsection.content: A specified officer may apply to a magistrate in accordance with subrule (3) for the issue of a warrant by the magistrate under subrule (5) in relation to the prisoner.
The application must be supported by information on oath and be made ex parte to a magistrate by a specified officer.

However, if the magistrate considers, in the circumstances of the case, that it is in the interests of justice for the proceedings relating to the application to be held inter partes, the magistrate may direct the proceedings to be so held.

subsection.leadIn: If the magistrate hearing the application is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the circumstances mentioned in subrule (6) exist, the magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing an officer of the Correctional Services Department to impose the following restrictions on the prisoner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the prisoner must not, within the period specified in the warrant—

subparagraph.content: connect with the particular legal representative or particular legal representatives; or

if the particular legal representative or particular legal representatives are engaged in legal work in a Hong Kong firm or certain Hong Kong firms—connect with any legal representative engaged in legal work in the Hong Kong firm or Hong Kong firms; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prisoner may, under these rules, connect with any other legal representative selected by the prisoner.

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the prisoner’s connection with a legal representative mentioned in subrule (5)(a)(i) or (ii) (relevant legal representative) will—

subparagraph.content: endanger national security; or
cause bodily harm to any person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prisoner has benefited from any criminal offence committed or allegedly committed by him or her, and the prisoner’s connection with a relevant legal representative will hinder the recovery of the benefit unless the authorization is given; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the prisoner’s connection with a relevant legal representative will pervert or obstruct the course of justice unless the authorization is given.

subsection.leadIn: If an application is made under subrule (2), then before the magistrate decides the application, the prisoner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not connect with the relevant legal representative; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, under these rules, connect with any other legal representative selected by the prisoner.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, for the purposes of this rule, authorize any officer of the Correctional Services Department (other than an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Superintendent).

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: means to connect by any means; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: includes to interview (whether conducted in person or by remote means), and to communicate by telephone or letter;

subsection.def: Hong Kong firm (香港律師行) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159);

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: means a barrister or solicitor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: includes a person who assists a barrister or solicitor’s performance of his or her functions as a barrister or solicitor;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Superintendent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department authorized under subrule (8).

subsection.content: If, after the issue of a warrant under rule 52A(5), a specified officer (as defined by rule 52A(9)) no longer has reasonable grounds to believe that the circumstances mentioned in rule 52A(6) exist, an officer of the Correctional Services Department must immediately cease to impose on the prisoner the restrictions under rule 52A(5).
If a warrant is issued under rule 52A(5) in relation to a prisoner, the prisoner may apply to a magistrate to vary or revoke the warrant.
An application made under rule 52A(2) or subrule (2) must be heard in a closed court.
Despite subrule (3), the magistrate hearing the application may, either on the magistrate’s own motion or on application by any party to the hearing, order the application to be heard in open court.

However, the magistrate concerned may only make an order under subrule (4) on being satisfied that doing so is necessary in the interests of justice and would not be contrary to the interests of national security.

section.name: s52C
section.heading: Power regarding restriction against prisoners from connecting with particular legal representatives by letter

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a warrant is issued under rule 52A(5); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application is made under rule 52A(2), and the magistrate has not decided the application.

subsection.leadIn: An officer of the Correctional Services Department may, within the period specified in the warrant or before the magistrate decides the application (as the case may be)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: stop any letter that contains communication between the prisoner and a relevant legal representative; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subject to subrule (3), open or read any letter to or from the prisoner for the purposes of paragraph (b).

subsection.leadIn: Any letter mentioned in subrule (2)(c)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may only be opened or read by an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Principal Officer;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: may only be opened or read in so far as it is necessary to confirm whether the letter contains communication between the prisoner and a relevant legal representative.

subsection.leadIn: If an officer of the Correctional Services Department stops any letter under subrule (2)(b), the Superintendent must inform, orally or in writing, the prisoner of the reason for doing so, and may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: return the letter to the sender; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: destroy the letter.

subsection.content: If any officer of the Correctional Services Department reads any letter under subrule (2)(c), and the letter does not contain communication between the prisoner and a relevant legal representative, the officer must not divulge the contents of the letter to any person.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Visits concerning legal consultation not to be forfeited
section.content: The visits under rule 52 are additional to the visits allowed under any other of the foregoing rules, and are not liable to forfeiture under rule 63.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Right of prisoner to petition
section.text: Every prisoner may petition the Chief Executive during the first year of his sentence and once every year thereafter unless the Superintendent considers that there is sufficient cause to justify additional petitions.

subdivision.name: SD8
subdivision.heading: Library Books and Other Reading Materials

section.name: s55
section.heading: Library
section.content: A library shall be provided in every prison, and subject to such conditions as the Commissioner may determine every prisoner shall be allowed to have library books and such other reading materials as are available and to exchange them as often as practicable.

subsection.content: A prisoner must not receive any publication from outside the prison except with the Commissioner’s approval.

subsection.leadIn: If the Superintendent has reasonable grounds to believe that, any publication (or part of the publication) approved under subrule (1) will bring about one or more of the following effects—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being contrary to the interests of national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: tending to cause the commission of any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: being detrimental to the rehabilitation of any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posing a threat to any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: posing a threat to the security, good order and discipline of the prison,

subsection.continued: the Superintendent may withhold and dispose of the publication (or part of the publication), so that a prisoner (or a category of prisoners) may not receive the publication (or the part of the publication).

section.name: s57
section.heading: Power of Superintendent to deal with reports against prisoners
section.content: The Superintendent or in his absence, the officer appointed to act for him and no other, shall deal with a report made against a prisoner.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Segregation of a prisoner against whom a report has been made
section.content: A prisoner who has been reported for an offence shall be kept apart from other prisoners pending adjudication.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Duty of Principal Officer before he accepts a report against a prisoner
section.content: It shall be the duty of the Principal Officer on duty before he accepts a report made against a prisoner, to inform such prisoner of the facts alleged against him and to afford him an opportunity of making his reply.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Duty to report immediately offences against prison discipline
section.content: Every offence against prison discipline shall be reported immediately and it shall be the duty of the Superintendent to investigate such reports not later than the following day, unless that day is a general holiday.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Offences against prison discipline
section.leadIn: Every prisoner shall be guilty of an offence against prison discipline if he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disobeys any order of the Superintendent or of any other officer of the Correctional Services Department, or any prison rules or other regulations or any directive issued from time to time by the Commissioner that are applicable to him; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: treats with disrespect any officer of the Correctional Services Department, or any person authorized to visit the prison; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is idle or negligent at work, or refuses to work;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: uses threatening, abusive or insulting words or behaves in a manner that expresses a threat, abuse or an insult; (L.N. 275 of 1997)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: commits any assault;

paragraph.name: g
h
paragraph.content: leaves his cell or dormitory or place of work or other appointed place without permission; (L.N. 353 of 1981)

paragraph.name: i
k
paragraph.leadIn: has in his possession—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any article that he is not authorized to have; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a greater quantity of any article than that he is authorized to have; (L.N. 275 of 1997)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: without authority gives to or receives from any person any article;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: in any way offends good order and discipline;

paragraph.name: r
paragraph.content: wilfully feigns or endeavours to cause illness or wilfully obstructs cure;

paragraph.name: s
paragraph.content: makes false and malicious allegations against an officer of the Correctional Services Department; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: u
paragraph.content: loses or, without reasonable excuse, damages or destroys any Government property; (G.N.A. 68 of 1961)

paragraph.name: v
paragraph.content: is found to have, without reasonable excuse, traces of a dangerous drug within the meaning of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134) in a sample of his urine; (L.N. 353 of 1981)

paragraph.name: x
paragraph.content: fights with any person; (L.N. 275 of 1997)

paragraph.name: y
paragraph.content: obstructs an officer of the Correctional Services Department in the execution of his duty; (L.N. 275 of 1997)

paragraph.name: z
paragraph.leadIn: with respect to any of the other offences enumerated in this rule—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: attempts to commit;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: incites another person to commit; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: assists another person in committing or attempting to commit,

section.name: s62
section.heading: Power of Superintendent as to offences against prison discipline
section.content: The Superintendent may interrogate any person touching any alleged offence against prison discipline and determine thereupon and punish the offender.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Punishment which may be imposed by the Superintendent

subsection.leadIn: The Superintendent may order a prisoner, who commits any of the offences enumerated in rule 61, to be punished by any one or more of the following punishments—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issuing a caution; (L.N. 275 of 1997)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: separate confinement for any period not exceeding 28 days;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: forfeiture of remission not exceeding 1 month but if the Superintendent considers that his power of punishment is insufficient, he shall refer the case to the Commissioner who may order forfeiture of remission not exceeding 3 months; (L.N. 178 of 1970; L.N. 242 of 1983; L.N. 275 of 1997)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: forfeiture of privileges for a period not exceeding 3 months;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: deprivation of earnings or part thereof;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: deduction from earnings of the cost of any Government property lost by the prisoner, or damaged or destroyed without reasonable excuse by the prisoner. (G.N.A. 68 of 1961; L.N. 275 of 1997)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Where a prisoner who is detained in custody on remand or awaiting trial or sentence commits an offence specified in rule 61, he may be punished if a prison sentence is subsequently given by forfeiture of any period of remission with which he would otherwise be credited under rule 69. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

Any prisoner who considers himself aggrieved by any order made by the Superintendent under this rule may, within 48 hours after the issue of such order, notify the Superintendent that he wishes to appeal to the Commissioner against such order, and the Superintendent shall forthwith notify the Commissioner accordingly and shall stay execution of the order pending the hearing of the appeal. (G.N.A. 68 of 1961)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: An appeal under subrule (2) may include an appeal in respect of the determination, on which the order that is being appealed under this rule is based, that an offence was committed. (L.N. 275 of 1997; L.N. 150 of 2014)

content.leadIn: Upon hearing the appeal, either by the prisoner in person or by him in writing, the Commissioner shall determine the appeal and may cancel, vary or confirm the order against which the appeal is made or may substitute therefor any other order which the Superintendent was competent to make under subrule (1): (L.N. 150 of 2014)
content.proviso: Provided that the Commissioner shall not substitute a greater punishment for a lesser punishment without first giving the prisoner to be punished an opportunity of showing cause why such punishment should not be increased. (G.N.A. 68 of 1961)

subsection.content: Where a case is referred to the Commissioner under subrule (1)(c) for an order for forfeiture of remission exceeding 1 month and the Commissioner, after considering the case, makes such an order, the prisoner may appeal in respect of the order to the Secretary for Security and subrules (2), (2A) and (3) apply to such an appeal except that a reference to the Superintendent in those subrules shall be read as a reference to the Commissioner and a reference to the Commissioner shall be read as a reference to the Secretary for Security. (L.N. 275 of 1997; L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s65
section.heading: Certificate of the Medical Officer that a prisoner is fit for punishment
section.content: No prisoner shall be subjected to separate confinement unless the Medical Officer has certified in writing that such prisoner is in a fit condition of health to undergo such punishment.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Prohibition of use of mechanical restraints

subsection.leadIn: Mechanical restraints shall not be used as a punishment or for any purpose except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to prevent a prisoner from injuring himself or others, or damaging property, or creating a disturbance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to ensure the safe custody of prisoners during removal or while outside any prison and in legal custody; or (L.N. 173 of 1992; L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: under the instructions of the Medical Officer.

subsection.content: When it appears to the Superintendent that it is necessary to place a prisoner under mechanical restraint for any of the reasons specified in subrule (1)(a), the Superintendent may order him to be so placed, and notice thereof shall forthwith be given to one of the visiting justices of the period and to the Medical Officer. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

The Medical Officer on receipt of the aforesaid notice shall forthwith inform the Superintendent whether he concurs in the order, and if he does not the Superintendent shall act in accordance with any recommendations which he makes.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Where under this rule the Medical Officer gives instructions for the use of a strait-jacket for the restraint of a violent prisoner he shall record the use of such restraint in his journal. (L.N. 242 of 1983)

No prisoner shall be kept under mechanical restraint longer than is necessary, or for a longer period than 24 hours unless upon the written order of one of the visiting justices of the period and the Commissioner. Such order shall specify the cause thereof and the time during which the prisoner is to be so kept, and shall be preserved by the Superintendent as his warrant.
Particulars of every case of mechanical restraint shall be forthwith entered by the Superintendent in his journal.
No mechanical means of restraint shall be used except of such patterns and in such manner and under such conditions as may be approved by the Chief Executive. (15 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s68
section.heading: Temporary confinement
section.content: The Superintendent may order any refractory or violent prisoner to be temporarily confined in a special cell certified for the purpose in the same manner as cells to which rule 3 applies, but no prisoner shall be confined in such a cell as a punishment or after he has ceased to be refractory or violent.

subsection.content: The Medical Officer may for the purpose of ensuring that a prisoner does not cause harm or hardship to himself or to some other person, order that prisoner to be confined in a protected room certified in the same manner as rooms to which rule 3 applies, but no prisoner shall be confined in such a room as a punishment or after he has ceased to be likely to cause such harm or hardship.
Particulars of every case of confinement under this rule shall be forthwith entered by the Medical Officer in his journal.

The Superintendent may, for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subrule (10), order the removal of a prisoner from association (either generally or for particular purposes) with other prisoners for a period of not more than 72 hours. (L.N. 174 of 2025)
No prisoner shall be removed from association under subrule (1) unless the Medical Officer has certified that the prisoner is fit for removal.

A prisoner removed from association under subrule (1) may make representations to the Superintendent in respect of the removal, and the Superintendent may, after considering the representations, arrange for the prisoner to resume association.

The Commissioner shall appoint for each prison a Board of Review consisting of the Superintendent, the Medical Officer and such other suitable officer as the Commissioner may select, to keep under review the progress of all prisoners removed from association and to make recommendations to the Commissioner as to their suitability for further removal under subrule (5) or to be returned to association. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

Where a prisoner is removed from association with other prisoners under an order (original order), the Commissioner may, for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subrule (10), order a further removal of the prisoner from association (either generally or for particular purposes) for a period of not more than 1 month on the expiry of the period of the original order. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

Where the Commissioner intends to order a further removal under subrule (5), he shall cause the prisoner to be notified of the intention and the reason for the further removal, and the prisoner may make representations in respect of the further removal to the Commissioner. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: In deciding whether to order a further removal of a prisoner under subrule (5), the Commissioner shall consider— (L.N. 150 of 2014; L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any recommendation of the Board of Review appointed under subrule (4);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where any recommendation of visiting justices is available, such recommendation;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where any representations have been made by the prisoner, such representations; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other relevant matter.

subsection.content: The Commissioner or the Superintendent may at any time arrange at his discretion for a prisoner to resume association, either generally or for particular purposes, and shall so arrange if the Medical Officer so advises on medical grounds.

subsection.leadIn: The purposes are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safeguarding national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: preventing or detecting any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: safeguarding the interests of any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: safeguarding any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: maintaining the security, good order and discipline of the prison. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

content.leadIn: A prisoner serving a sentence of imprisonment for an actual term of more than 1 month may, on the ground of his industry and good conduct, be granted remission in accordance with the provisions of this rule:
content.proviso: Provided that this rule shall not permit the reduction of the actual term to less than 31 days.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: However, if a prisoner serves a sentence in respect of the prisoner’s conviction of an offence endangering national security, the prisoner must not be granted remission under subrule (1) unless the Commissioner is satisfied that the prisoner’s being granted remission will not be contrary to the interests of national security. (6 of 2024 s. 152)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: To avoid doubt, subsection (1A) applies whether the sentence of the prisoner mentioned in that subsection was imposed before, on or after the commencement* of that subsection. (6 of 2024 s. 152)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: If a prisoner is not granted remission because of a decision made by the Commissioner under subsection (1A), the Commissioner must, after making the decision, review the decision annually. (6 of 2024 s. 152)

The remission granted under this rule shall not exceed one-third of the total of the actual term and any period spent in custody taken into account under section 67A of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) (which relates to the computation of a sentence of imprisonment).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this rule—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: consecutive terms of imprisonment shall be treated as one term.

subsection.content: This rule shall have effect subject to any disciplinary award or forfeiture of remission, and shall not apply to a prisoner serving a sentence of imprisonment for life.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: This rule shall not apply in the case of a sentence of imprisonment passed before 12 August 1983, and in any such case revoked rule 69 shall apply. (L.N. 112 of 1985)

subsection.name: 4B
subsection.content: No remission shall be granted in respect of a prisoner to whom the Post-Release Supervision of Prisoners Ordinance (Cap. 475) applies unless the Commissioner has been informed pursuant to section 7(3) of that Ordinance that no supervision order under that Ordinance is to be made in respect of that prisoner. (L.N. 417 of 1996)

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: actual term (實際刑期) means the term of a sentence of imprisonment as reduced by section 67A of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: revoked rule 69 (已廢除的第69條) means the rule 69 of these rules that was deleted by the Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Ordinance 1983 (46 of 1983). (L.N. 112 of 1985)

section.name: s70
section.heading: Application of the Pensions Ordinance, the Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations
section.content: The Pensions Ordinance (Cap. 89), the Pension Benefits Ordinance (Cap. 99), the Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations for the time being in force save in so far as they are inconsistent with these rules shall apply to all officers of the Correctional Services Department and other persons employed in the prisons subject nevertheless to any special considerations in respect of the appointment of any particular officer or person.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Duty of officer to obey orders of superiors
section.content: Every officer of the Correctional Services Department shall obey the lawful commands and orders of his superior in rank and of any officer placed in authority over him.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Duty of officer to direct attention to sick prisoners
section.content: Every officer of the Correctional Services Department shall direct the attention of the Superintendent to any prisoner (whether he complains or not) who appears to be out of health or whose state of mind appears to be deserving of special notice and care, and the Superintendent shall without delay bring such cases to the notice of the Medical Officer.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Prohibition of certain dealings
section.leadIn: An officer of the Correctional Services Department shall not— (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have any pecuniary or other dealing whatsoever with or on behalf of any prisoner, or employ any prisoner on his private account;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sell or let, nor allow to be sold or let, nor be interested in the selling or letting of, any article to a prisoner;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: receive, at any time or on any pretext whatsoever, any money, fee, or gratuity of any kind for the admission of any visitors to the prison or to prisoners, or from or on behalf of any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: borrow money from any contractor for the supply of food or other articles for the use of the prison;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: directly or indirectly, have any interest in any contract for the supply of food or other articles for the use of the prison, nor shall he, under any pretext whatsoever, receive any fee or gratuity from any such person;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: lend money on interest, or in consideration of the payment or promise of repayment of a larger sum, or on any other valuable consideration whatsoever.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Prohibition of conveyance of property in and out of prison
section.content: An officer of the Correctional Services Department shall not bring in or carry out, or knowingly allow to be brought in or carried out, of the prison any article of private, or Government, property except in the execution of his duty or with the authority of the Superintendent.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Prohibition of use, consumption or possession of intoxicating liquor, etc., in prison by officer

subsection.content: An officer of the Correctional Services Department shall not use or consume in the prison, nor take into the prison, nor have therein, except as required by these rules, any intoxicating liquor, opium or other drug, or any other unauthorized article. (L.N. 353 of 1981)
An officer of the Correctional Services Department may carry in a prison money or tobacco for his own personal use. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

section.name: s76
section.heading: Prohibition of communications
section.leadIn: An officer of the Correctional Services Department who, without lawful authority, makes any communication to any person that might reasonably be capable of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: interfering with the privacy of a prisoner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: affecting prison security,

section.continued: commits a breach of confidence and shall be liable to dismissal.

subdivision.name: SD2
subdivision.heading: Senior Officers

subsection.content: The Commissioner shall, subject to the orders and directions of the Chief Executive, have the administrative command and direction of all prisons and such other institutions as may be placed under his control, and the officers of the Correctional Services Department and may transfer for duty anywhere within Hong Kong any such officer. (L.N. 30 of 1982; L.N. 213 of 1986; 15 of 1999 s. 3)

The Commissioner may, subject to the provisions of these rules and to the orders and directions of the Chief Executive, from time to time frame orders and regulations for the observance of all officers of the Correctional Services Department. (L.N. 30 of 1982; 15 of 1999 s. 3)
The Commissioner shall periodically visit and inspect all institutions under his control.

The Commissioner shall issue such orders as may be necessary for the government of all institutions under his control in conformity with these rules, and for the discipline of the persons, other than subordinate officers, employed therein.
The Commissioner shall pay into the general revenue all moneys received by him in payment of fines. (L.N. 30 of 1982; L.N. 254 of 1999)

The Commissioner may permit persons of respectability to view the institutions under his control at such times as he may approve. Visitors shall, at all times, be accompanied by an officer of the Correctional Services Department. (L.N. 30 of 1982)
The Commissioner shall ensure compliance with the provisions of section 20 of the Ordinance at all times.
The Commissioner may exercise all or any of the powers conferred by these rules on the Superintendent and may perform all or any of the duties prescribed for him.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Duties of Deputy Commissioner
section.content: The Deputy Commissioner shall, under the Commissioner, be responsible for the general control of the Correctional Services Department.

subdivision.crossHeading: Assistant Commissioner, Chief Superintendent and Senior Superintendent

section.name: s78A
section.heading: Powers and duties of Assistant Commissioner, Chief Superintendent and Senior Superintendent
section.content: An Assistant Commissioner, a Chief Superintendent and a Senior Superintendent may exercise all the powers and may perform all the duties conferred or imposed by these rules on a Superintendent.

section.name: s78B
section.heading: Duties of Assistant Commissioner
section.content: An Assistant Commissioner shall, under the Deputy Commissioner, be responsible for the administration, management and operational activities of the Correctional Services Department.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Duty to supervise matters connected with prison
section.content: The Superintendent (or other officer in charge of a prison, whatever his or her rank may be) shall supervise and control all matters in connexion with the prison of which he or she may be in charge and shall be responsible to the Commissioner for the conduct and treatment of the officers of the Correctional Services Department and prisoners under his control and for the due observance by such officers and prisoners of the provisions of these rules and of all orders issued thereunder.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Duty to conform to rules and to enforce their observance

subsection.content: The Superintendent shall strictly conform to these rules, and he shall be responsible for their due observance by others.
The Superintendent shall keep a journal in which he shall enter such matters as he may be directed.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Duty to maintain discipline
section.content: The Superintendent shall observe the conduct of the subordinate officers and other persons employed in the prisons and shall be responsible for the maintenance of strict discipline throughout the prison.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Duty to instruct every officer in his duties
section.content: The Superintendent shall ensure that every officer is fully instructed in his duties.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Duty to transmit complaints
section.content: The Superintendent shall transmit to the Commissioner without delay any report or complaint which any subordinate officer or other person employed in the prisons may make to him. He shall on no account suppress it, but he may make such explanation as may appear to him to be necessary.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Duty as to gates and keys
section.content: The Superintendent shall ensure that all gates are locked at the proper times and that all keys of the prison are kept in the authorized place or in the possession of the authorized officers, and he shall not allow any key of the prison to be taken outside the prison.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Duty to take precaution and make inspection
section.leadIn: The Superintendent shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take every precaution against fire or the escape of prisoners;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause to be thoroughly examined daily all the wards, cells, bolts and locks of the prison;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: cause to be inspected weekly all the rooms, workshops, halls and dormitories thereof, and a record to be kept of such inspections; and (L.N. 353 of 1981)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ensure that adequate measures of security are taken in the armoury. (L.N. 65 of 1969)

section.name: s86
section.heading: Power to search officers and other persons

subsection.content: The Superintendent may, at any time, order the person or property of any subordinate officer or other person employed in the prisons to be searched if he has reason to suspect that such officer or person is trafficking in articles prohibited by law.
All such searches shall be recorded in a book which shall be shown to the Commissioner on his inspections.

The Superintendent may detain any subordinate officer or other person employed in the prisons who has been searched by his order under subrule (1) if he has reason to believe that an offence has been committed by such officer or person. (L.N. 2 of 1974; L.N. 150 of 2014)

If the Superintendent detains any subordinate officer or other person employed in the prisons under subrule (3), he shall, as soon as he is able to do so, take such officer or person to the nearest police station or deliver him into the custody of a police officer. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s87
section.heading: Duty to ensure that prohibited articles are not brought into prison by visitors
section.content: The Superintendent shall take proper means to ensure that articles prohibited by law and articles which, in his opinion, are objectionable are not brought into the prison by visitors.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Power to demand particulars from visitors and to search them

subsection.content: The Superintendent may demand the name, address and evidence of identification of any visitor to a prisoner and may, on reasonable grounds of suspicion, require every such male visitor to be searched, and may direct a female to search every such female visitor provided that such a search shall, under no circumstances, take place in the presence of another visitor or any prisoner. (L.N. 65 of 1969; L.N. 353 of 1981)
Every such visitor who objects to such a search may be refused permission to see a prisoner in which event the Superintendent shall record the fact in his journal.
The Superintendent may remove from the prison any such visitor whose conduct is improper in which event he shall record the fact in his journal.
The Superintendent shall frequently test the quality and quantity of the rations supplied to the prisoners.
He shall, from time to time, visit the prisoners at their meals, and shall inquire into any complaint which may be made to him regarding their rations.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Duty to ensure cleanliness
section.leadIn: The Superintendent shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: enforce the highest possible degree of cleanliness—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in every part of the prison;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the persons of the prisoners and their clothes and bedding;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that the clothing and bedding of prisoners are in proper repair.

subsection.leadIn: The Superintendent shall deliver daily to the Medical Officer separate lists containing the names and numbers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of prisoners under punishment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of prisoners who have complained of sickness or any other ailment, whether he considers such complaints groundless or not.

subsection.leadIn: The Superintendent shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take care that no prisoner is subject to any punishment which the Medical Officer is satisfied the prisoner is incapable of undergoing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider the Medical Officer’s recommendations for the supply of any additional bedding, or the alteration of the diet of any prisoner, or to any alteration of discipline or treatment in the case of any prisoner whose mind or body requires it. If he is unable to approve any such recommendation of the Medical Officer, he shall so inform him in writing of the reasons for refusal, and shall report the facts to the Commissioner.

subsection.content: The Superintendent shall report to the Medical Officer any case of abnormal behaviour, insanity or apparent insanity among prisoners. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

section.name: s92
section.heading: Duty to visit hospital
section.content: The Superintendent shall make daily visits to the hospital and see all prisoners therein.
