He shall satisfy himself that proper arrangements are made for the safe custody of the sick prisoners, and that discipline is maintained, so far as is consistent with the medical treatment prescribed for them.

section.name: s93
section.heading: Duty as to sanitary condition of prison

subsection.leadIn: The Superintendent shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pay attention to the ventilation, drainage, and sanitary condition of the prison, and take such measures as may be necessary to maintain them in perfect order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the company of the Medical Officer at intervals not exceeding 2 weeks examine the washing-places, baths and closets. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

subsection.content: Every officer shall report as soon as they are brought to his notice, any defects discovered in such washing-places, baths and closets.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Duty to inspect prison and prisoners
section.leadIn: The Superintendent shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exercise a close and constant personal supervision of the whole prison;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: visit and inspect daily every part of the prison where prisoners are employed or confined;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: visit the prison by night at least twice a fortnight;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: give special attention to every prisoner who for any reason is confined to his cell.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Duty as to reports and complaints

subsection.content: The Superintendent shall hear daily all reports at such hours as may be most convenient.

The Superintendent shall ensure that every prisoner having a complaint to make or a request to prefer to him shall have ample facilities for so doing, and he shall take all the necessary steps to redress all grievances so far as is possible.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Duty to assist police
section.content: The Superintendent shall assist the police in the identification of prisoners, and shall, for this purpose, give all such information within his knowledge.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Duty to check stores, transport and prisoners’ property
section.leadIn: The Superintendent shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exercise a general supervision over stores and transport; (L.N. 65 of 1969)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at frequent intervals check items in stores against the numbers or quantities in the store ledger in order to ascertain whether they agree;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: from time to time check moneys and property belonging to prisoners and ensure that they are properly kept.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Duty towards prisoners committed for trial
section.content: The Superintendent shall, on the occasion of a prisoner who is committed for trial, being served with a copy of the indictment, with the notice of trial endorsed thereon or annexed thereto, ask him if he wishes to see a legal adviser or if he wishes to call witnesses for his defence, and shall at once inform the police authorities in order that any such witnesses may, if required, be summoned to appear at his trial.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Duty to produce prisoners before Court of First Instance or District Court
section.text: The Superintendent shall be responsible for the production of all prisoners for trial before the Court of First Instance or District Court, and he shall take measures as he may deem necessary for their safe custody.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Responsibility for discharge of prisoners
section.content: The Superintendent shall be responsible for the discharge of all prisoners as soon as they are entitled to be released for any reason whatsoever.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Duty to report inability to restrain a violent prisoner
section.content: The Superintendent shall whenever a violent prisoner cannot be restrained by normal means and whose violence is, in his opinion, due to the prisoner’s mental condition, or disease report the fact to the Medical Officer, and shall act on his instructions.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Duty to give notice of death of prisoner

subsection.content: Upon the death of a prisoner the Superintendent shall give immediate notice thereof to the coroner, the Commissioner and the Commissioner of Police and, where practicable, to the nearest relative of the deceased.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: In the case of a prisoner undergoing trial, notice shall also be given to the judge, District Judge or magistrate presiding thereat.
After any death inquiry on a prisoner the Superintendent shall report to the Commissioner the finding and such other facts of importance as may arise at such inquiry.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Devolution and delegation of duties and powers

subsection.content: In the absence of the Superintendent his duties and powers shall devolve upon the officer detailed by the Commissioner to act in his place.
The Superintendent may delegate to the Chief Officer such duties and powers as the Commissioner may, from time to time, approve.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Prohibition against absence without permission
section.content: The Chief Officer shall not absent himself from his duties without the permission of the Superintendent.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Duty to assist in the supervision of officers and prisoners
section.content: The Chief Officer shall assist in the general superintendence of the officers of the Correctional Services Department and prisoners and in the details of duties, and shall report to the Superintendent any misconduct or disobedience or orders on the part of the subordinate officers or prisoners.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Responsibility as to execution of duties
section.content: The Chief Officer shall be responsible to the Superintendent that the details of duties connected with the prison are carried out with promptness and regularity, and in strict accordance with these rules and the Superintendent’s orders. He shall also enforce the greatest economy.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Duty to ensure fitness for duty
section.content: The Chief Officer shall ensure that the officers of the Correctional Services Department are in all respects fit for, and properly acquainted with, their duties. He shall also ensure that new orders are communicated to them.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Duty to restrain tendency to oppression
section.content: The Chief Officer shall restrain by his authority every tendency to oppression or undue harshness on the part of the officers of the Correctional Services Department.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Duty to communicate circumstances affecting discipline, etc.
section.content: The Chief Officer shall at once communicate to the Superintendent every circumstance, which may come to his knowledge, likely to affect the security, health or discipline of the prisoners or the efficiency of the officers of the Correctional Services Department or anything which may in any way require his attention.

section.name: s112
section.heading: Duty to search prisoners
section.content: The Chief Officer shall take care that every prisoner on admission is strictly searched and that all knives, weapons, instruments, money, dangerous drug within the meaning of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134), tobacco or anything prohibited by law, or by the Superintendent’s orders, or which is likely to facilitate escape, or which is, in the opinion of the Superintendent, objectionable, are taken away from him.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Duty to ensure recording of particulars on admission of prisoners
section.content: The Chief Officer shall ensure that the officer in charge of the reception of prisoners records in the register provided for that purpose the name, age, height, weight, features, particular marks and general appearance of every prisoner on admission, with such other measurements and particulars as may be required.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Duty to record particulars of prisoners’ property

subsection.content: The Chief Officer shall cause to be recorded in a book provided for that purpose the particulars of all articles, including clothing, and other effects, taken from prisoners and all such other things as may be sent in from time to time on their account, together with the dates of their receipt and restoration.

The Chief Officer shall cause all such articles and things to be kept in a suitable place to be provided for that purpose, and shall cause them to be restored to the prisoners on their discharge, except articles which he has found necessary to destroy, or such money, or such property as the Superintendent may deem fit to confiscate, or to allow prisoners to have to assist them in their defence on their trial. (L.N. 275 of 1997)

section.name: s115
section.heading: Duty to count prisoners
section.content: The Chief Officer shall cause all the prisoners to be counted 5 times a day, and shall satisfy himself that the number is correct.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Miscellaneous duties
section.leadIn: The Chief Officer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make daily inspection of every part of the prison and ensure its cleanliness and good order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure the effectiveness of the measures of security employed in the yards and other places;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: pay special attention to prisoners under punishment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ensure that every prisoner who wishes to see the Superintendent is given an opportunity to do so;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: ensure that ladders, planks, ropes, chains and anything likely to facilitate escape are not left exposed in the yards;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: frequently visit the workshops, yards and corridors to ensure that prisoners are kept at their work;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: at intervals not exceeding 7 days visit the wards at night without previous notice to ensure that the officers on duty are on the alert; (L.N. 353 of 1981; 31 of 1983 s. 8)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: diligently observe the behaviour of all officers to ensure that they adhere strictly to these rules and the orders of the Commissioner; (31 of 1983 s. 8)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: report immediately to the Superintendent any neglect of duty or misconduct which may come to his knowledge.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Duty to accompany visiting justices
section.content: An officer not below the rank of Chief Officer shall accompany the visiting justices in their visits of inspection and bring before them any prisoner who wishes to see them.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Duty as to food
section.leadIn: The Chief Officer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: frequently attend the issuing of the prisoners’ meals; (L.N. 353 of 1981)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that every article of food supplied for the use of the prisoners is sound and of good quality;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ensure that the scales, weights and measures in use in the prison for the issue and distribution of provisions and stores are accurate and in good order.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Duty as to personal cleanliness of prisoners
section.content: The Chief Officer shall ensure that the prisoners’ clothing is kept in good state of repair, their hair kept trimmed, and their washing, hair clipping and personal ablutions attended to.

section.name: s120
section.heading: Duty as to keys
section.content: The Chief Officer shall carry out the orders of the Commissioner as to the safe custody of keys during the night.

section.name: s121
section.heading: Duty to make weekly inspections of officers’ quarters
section.content: The Chief Officer shall make weekly inspections of the quarters occupied by officers of the Correctional Services Department, and shall report the result of his inspection to the Superintendent.

section.name: s122
section.heading: Duty to supervise fire party
section.content: The Chief Officer shall supervise the exercise of the fire party at least once in every month.

section.name: s123
section.heading: Performance of duties in absence of Chief Officer
section.content: In the absence of the Chief Officer his duties shall be performed by the officer detailed by the Superintendent to perform them.

section.name: s126
section.heading: Principal Officers to have particular charge of certain prisoners and parts of the prison
section.content: The Superintendent shall place in the immediate charge of the Principal Officers certain prisoners and parts of the prison and they shall be responsible for the maintenance of proper order and discipline among such prisoners and in such portions of the prison.

section.name: s127
section.heading: Duty to ensure punctuality at meals
section.content: The Principal Officers shall ensure that the officers under them report for duty and leave for and return from their meals punctually, and it shall be their duty to report any unpunctuality to the Superintendent.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Miscellaneous duties of Principal Officers
section.leadIn: The Principal Officers shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensure that all prisoners are kept strictly to their labour;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: ensure strict adherence to these rules and to the orders of any senior officer; (L.N. 353 of 1981)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: report immediately to the Chief Officer any neglect or misconduct on the part of any officer of the Correctional Services Department or prisoner which may come to their knowledge; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: superintend the issuing of prisoners’ meals. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

section.name: s129
section.heading: Duty to attend to orders regarding punishment
section.content: The Principal Officers shall personally attend to the execution of orders as to punishment inflicted on prisoners, and shall ensure that all prisoners under punishment are provided with necessaries.

section.name: s130
section.heading: Duty to inspect parts of the prison, water cocks and fire appliances
section.leadIn: The Principal Officers shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: frequently inspect every part of the prison placed under their immediate charge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inspect all locks, bars, bolts and other measures of security to ensure that they are in good order;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ensure that the prisoners are not in possession of any article without authority, for which purpose they may frequently search the prisoners;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ensure that fire appliances are in good working order;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: ensure that the fire buckets are at all times kept properly filled;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: ensure that the water pipes and cocks are in good working order, and that no leakages exist.

section.name: s131
section.heading: Duty to check prisoners and to supervise their locking up
section.content: The Principal Officers shall check the number of prisoners in their immediate charge and shall supervise the unlocking and locking up of such prisoners.

section.name: s132
section.heading: Duty to receive keys
section.content: The Principal Officers shall, after the locking up of all prisoners in their immediate charge, receive all keys and hand them over to the officer in charge of the next shift.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Performance of duties in the absence of a Principal Officer
section.content: In the absence of a Principal Officer his duties shall be performed by the officer detailed by the Superintendent to perform them.

section.name: s134
section.heading: Duty of subordinate officers to obey superior officers
section.content: Subordinate officers shall obey the lawful commands and orders of the Commissioner, their superiors in rank and of any officer placed in authority over them and shall perform such duties as may be ordered by them.

section.name: s135
section.heading: Duty to examine measures of security and to seize articles for the possession of which no authority has been given
section.content: Subordinate officers shall frequently examine the locks, bars, bolts and other measures of security, the state of the cells and the bedding of the prisoners, and shall seize and deliver forthwith to a superior officer all articles for the possession of which no authority has been given.

section.name: s136
section.heading: Prison keys
section.content: Officers of the Correctional Services Department shall keep their keys attached on their key chains and shall on leaving their posts deliver them to the officer appointed to receive them. They shall on no account take their keys out of the prison.

section.name: s137
section.heading: Duty to be correctly and neatly dressed
section.content: Subordinate officers shall, when on duty, appear correctly and neatly dressed in the uniform approved for their rank.

section.name: s138
section.heading: Miscellaneous duties
section.leadIn: Subordinate officers shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: treat the prisoners with kindness and humanity;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: listen patiently to any prisoner who has a complaint to make;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inform the Chief Officer when any prisoner desires to see him or the Superintendent;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: be firm in maintaining order and discipline and in enforcing observance of these rules and the orders of any senior officer. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

subsection.content: Subordinate officers may be granted leave on any day in lieu of any general holiday.
Casual leave and vacation leave may be granted in accordance with government regulations. (15 of 1999 s. 3)
Medical treatment and sick leave may be granted to or withheld from subordinate officers under the provisions of government regulations. (15 of 1999 s. 3)

Every officer of the Correctional Services Department received into hospital for observation and who is subsequently certified to be malingering shall receive no pay, for the period during which he was under observation, and all hospital expenses and charges incidental thereto shall be paid by such officer. (L.N. 30 of 1982)

Subordinate officers shall go into hospital when ordered to do so by the Medical Officer and shall remain in hospital so long as the Medical Officer in charge of the hospital directs. They shall, while in hospital, obey all hospital regulations.
Subordinate officers shall not sleep out of such quarters as the Government may assign to them without the permission of a Superintendent.
A subordinate officer occupying Government quarters shall not let lodgings therein.

section.name: s141A
section.heading: Quarters to be delivered up on resignation etc. of officer
section.content: If an officer of the Correctional Services Department or other person employed in the prisons is discharged or dismissed, or resigns, retires or dies, the quarters which he has occupied shall, when the Commissioner so requires, be delivered up to the Government.

section.name: s142
section.heading: Application of rules 134 to 140 to persons employed in prisons
section.content: Rules 134 to 140 inclusive shall apply to all other persons employed in the prisons.

section.name: s143
section.heading: General duties
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have the medical charge and shall be responsible for the treatment when sick of all the prisoners in a prison;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give medical advice and assistance, including medicines, to the officers of the Correctional Services Department and their families; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: keep such statistical records and furnish such returns and reports as may be ordered by the Commissioner relative to the health and medical treatment of such officers and prisoners, the sanitary conditions of a prison and of the quarters occupied by such officers.

section.name: s144
section.heading: Duty to prisoners
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: visit every prison under his charge at times to be arranged by the Commissioner, or at such other times as may be necessary;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every day see such of the prisoners who complain of illness and report in writing to the Superintendent their fitness or otherwise for labour;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: make daily visits to the sick in the prison hospital;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: attend at once any officer of the Correctional Services Department or prisoner on the receipt of information that he is seriously ill; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: make daily visits to all prisoners undergoing punishment, in separate confinement, or under special discipline;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: make daily examinations of the newly admitted prisoners and pass them fit for labour or otherwise;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: frequently examine the washing-places, baths and other provision for purposes of cleanliness and sanitation to ensure the efficient working thereof, and report forthwith all defects in connexion therewith to the Superintendent; and (L.N. 174 of 2025)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: immediately before punishment is inflicted examine the prisoner and satisfy himself that he is both mentally and physically fit to undergo punishment, and shall make such recommendations for preventing injury to the prisoner’s health as he may deem necessary, and the Superintendent shall carry such recommendations into effect. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

section.name: s145
section.heading: Duty to examine prisoners’ food, bedding, etc.
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: examine frequently the cooked and uncooked food of the prisoners;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: report to the Superintendent as to the quality of such food;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: report as to the sufficiency of clothing and bedding;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: report any deficiency in the quality or quantity of water;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: report any cause whatsoever which may affect the health of the prisoners.

section.name: s146
section.heading: Duty to prevent epidemic
section.content: The Medical Officer shall take such action and employ such treatment as he may consider necessary or expedient for the prevention, as far as possible, or mitigation of any epidemic or endemic contagious or infectious disease in a prison.

section.name: s147
section.heading: Duty to give written directions for the segregation of prisoners
section.content: The Medical Officer shall give written directions for the segregation of prisoners having infectious complaints, or suspected of having them, and for cleansing, disinfecting or destroying any infected apparel or bedding.

section.name: s148
section.heading: Duty to make special reports regarding a prisoner’s health

subsection.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: report in writing to the Superintendent any prisoner who, in his opinion, it is necessary so to report for medical reasons;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make recommendations which appear to him to be necessary for the alteration of the discipline or treatment of such prisoner, or for the supply of additional articles to him.

subsection.content: The Medical Officer shall make his recommendations in writing to the Commissioner for transmission to the Chief Executive whenever he is of opinion that the life of any prisoner will be endangered by his continuance in prison, or that any sick prisoner will not survive his sentence, or is totally or permanently unfit for prison sentence. (15 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s149
section.heading: Duty to keep a journal
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall enter in a journal to be kept in the prison—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any observation or suggestion he may deem necessary to make regarding the food served to prisoners or with regard to any other matter connected with their health;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a short daily record of all sick prisoners under treatment containing particulars as to whether they are in hospital or not, their names, the nature of their complaints, and the treatment prescribed.

section.name: s150
section.heading: Duty relating to the death of a prisoner
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall on the death of any prisoner forthwith enter in his journal the following particulars—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time the deceased was taken ill;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the time the illness was first reported to him;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the nature of the disease;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the time of death, with an account of the appearances after death (in cases when a post mortem examination has been made) and such further remarks which, in his opinion, are necessary.

section.name: s151
section.heading: Duty to examine prisoner on discharge
section.content: The Medical Officer shall examine every prisoner on the day prior to his discharge from prison and certify as to his fitness to leave the prison, and to such other particulars regarding him as may be necessary.

section.name: s152
section.heading: Power to appoint hospital orderlies
section.content: The Superintendent may place at the disposal of the Medical Officer well-behaved prisoners for the purpose of attending on the sick and for the performance of such other work in connexion with a hospital as may be necessary.

section.name: s153
section.heading: Duty to report irregularity
section.content: The Medical Officer shall report to the Superintendent any irregularity in a prison hospital which may come to his knowledge or any difficulty or obstruction which he may meet with in the performance of his duty.

subsection.content: The Medical Officer shall ensure that all medicines and stimulants are securely locked up and not accessible to any prisoner.
Medicine shall not be administered to any prisoner without the Medical Officer’s instructions except in case of urgent necessity.

section.name: s156
section.heading: Duty to submit journal to Commissioner
section.content: The Medical Officer shall submit his journal for the Commissioner’s inspection at least once every month and shall report at the same time on the condition of the prison and the state of health of the prisoners and officers, recording any want of cleanliness, proper drainage, warmth, ventilation, or any insufficiency or bad quality of the bedding, clothing, provisions or water.

section.name: s157
section.heading: Duty to submit annual report
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall, as soon as possible after the 31 December in each year, deliver to the Commissioner for transmission to the Director of Health a report containing— (L.N. 353 of 1981; L.N. 76 of 1989)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of sick among the prisoners for the year just ended;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the rate of mortality among the prisoners;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: particulars as to the state of the sanitary conditions of the prisons;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the type of diseases most prevalent in the prisons, and the defects in the construction or management of the prisons to which such diseases may be attributable;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the precautions to be taken to prevent the recurrence of such diseases.

section.name: s158
section.heading: Duty to report use of strait-jacket or confinement in protected room to Commissioner
section.leadIn: The Medical Officer shall report to the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the use of a strait-jacket for the restraint of a violent prisoner under rule 67; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the confinement in a protected room of any prisoner under rule 68A.

section.name: s159
section.heading: Duty to conform to rules and Commissioner’s order, etc.
section.content: The Medical Officer shall conform to these rules and the Commissioner’s orders, and shall support the Superintendent in the maintenance of discipline and order and assist him in the safe custody of the prisoners.

section.name: s161
section.heading: Duty to draw attention of Superintendent to prisoners with suicidal intentions
section.content: The Medical Officer shall draw the attention of the Superintendent to any prisoner who he may have reason to think has suicidal intentions in order that special observation may be kept on such prisoner, and the Superintendent shall, without delay, direct that such prisoner be observed at frequent intervals.

section.name: s162
section.heading: Hours of duty
section.content: A Chief Officer when appointed to a prison hospital shall be on duty at such hours as the Commissioner may direct and shall not absent himself from his duties without the permission of the Superintendent.

section.name: s163
section.heading: Duty as to drugs, prescriptions, etc.

subsection.content: The Chief Officer appointed to a prison hospital shall have the charge and custody of all the drugs, surgery stock, surgical instruments and appliances, and shall be responsible to ensure that they are kept in good and proper order in accordance with the instructions of the Medical Officer. (G.N.A. 68 of 1961; L.N. 44 of 1966)
He may, if qualified, compound the prescriptions issued by the Medical Officer and shall issue the surgical stock and medicines in accordance with his instructions.
He shall not, except in cases of urgent necessity, issue any medicines or surgical appliances without the sanction of the Medical Officer.
He shall keep a record of the receipt and issue of drugs and shall perform such other clerical work in connexion with his hospital duties as he may be directed.
He shall attend on the Medical Officer as directed and shall give such assistance in the examination of prisoners or in the performance of operations as may be required.
He shall, irrespective of the time, sleep in the prison hospital if required so to do in cases of emergency or serious illness.
He shall wear uniform if so ordered.

section.name: s164
section.heading: Performance of duties in absence of Chief Officer
section.content: In the absence of the Chief Officer appointed to a prison hospital, his duties shall be performed by a Principal Officer.

section.name: s165
section.heading: Rules relating to Chief Officers on hospital duties to apply to Principal Officers on hospital duties
section.content: The rules relating to a Chief Officer appointed to a prison hospital shall be equally applicable to a Principal Officer on duty in a prison hospital, whose further duty shall be to assist the Chief Officer appointed to the prison hospital and to perform such other duties as the Commissioner, Superintendent or the Medical Officer may order.

section.name: s166
section.heading: Duty to carry out medical instructions of Medical Officer
section.content: Subordinate officers on duty in a prison hospital shall carry out the medical instructions of the Medical Officer. In all other respects they shall be subject to these rules and to the Commissioner’s orders.

section.name: s167
section.heading: Power of chaplains to visit prisoners

subsection.content: The chaplains of the various denominations appointed by the Chief Executive shall have access to the prisoners at all reasonable times. (15 of 1999 s. 3)
The chaplains shall conduct religious services on such days as are suitable in the prisons in their charge. (L.N. 353 of 1981)

section.name: s168
section.heading: Duty of chaplains to report abuses, etc.
section.leadIn: The chaplains shall, as soon as is conveniently possible, inform the Superintendent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of any abuse or impropriety in the prison which may come to their knowledge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whenever they are of opinion that the mind of a prisoner may be injuriously affected by any punishment awarded.

subsection.content: The chaplains shall administer the Holy Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper on suitable occasions to all prisoners who wish to communicate.
The time of the celebration of Holy Communion shall be notified in advance, and it shall be the duty of the communicants to inform the chaplains of their intention before the appointed times.

subsection.leadIn: Despite rules 167 and 169, the Superintendent may, for one or more purposes mentioned in subrule (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: impose any restrictions or conditions on any relevant function of the chaplains; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prohibit the performance of the function.

subsection.leadIn: The purposes are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safeguarding national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: preventing or detecting any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: rehabilitating any prisoner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: safeguarding any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: maintaining the security, good order and discipline of the prison.

section.name: s170
section.heading: Duty to furnish report
section.content: The chaplains shall, as soon as possible after 31 December in each year, send to the Commissioner a report containing all matters connected with their office which they consider necessary to bring to the notice of the Commissioner.

section.name: s171
section.heading: Responsibility of Secretary
section.content: The Secretary shall have charge of the clerical staff and shall be responsible for the proper keeping of stores and accounts.

section.name: s172
section.heading: Responsibilities and duties
section.leadIn: The Stores Control Officer and every Sub-storekeeper shall— (G.N.A. 68 of 1961; L.N. 65 of 1969)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be responsible for the due receipt, custody and issue of all stores in such manner as the Commissioner may, from time to time, direct;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that all stores are kept in an orderly and systematic manner in the appointed place;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be responsible for the proper marking, before issue, of all articles which require marking;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ensure the safe custody of all stores and shall keep them properly locked up except when receiving or issuing goods;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: be responsible every day before leaving the prison for the proper locking up of all stores;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: leave with the Gate Keeper the store-room keys securely locked up in a box of which only the Superintendent and himself shall have a key;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: not concern himself with any business not connected with his office.

section.name: s173
section.heading: Interchangeability of duties
section.content: The members of the clerical staff shall be treated as a whole and their duties may be interchanged, at any time, at the discretion of the Commissioner.

section.name: s174
section.heading: Duty to attend to their duties

subsection.content: The clerks shall attend to their duties at such hours as the Commissioner may direct.
The clerks shall be allowed leave on Saturday afternoons and general holidays or time off in lieu thereof when ordered to report for duty on such days.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Special Rules for Particular Class of Prisoners

subsection.leadIn: The following rules shall apply to persons (hereinafter referred to as prisoners awaiting trial) committed to prison for safe custody in any of the following circumstances—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on their committal for trial for any indictable offence;

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: on their detention pursuant to an order of transfer made under section 88 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227); (L.N. 65 of 1969)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on their detention pending the hearing before a magistrate of a charge against them on an indictable offence; (L.N. 65 of 1969)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: on their detention pending the hearing of an information or complaint against them;

paragraph.name: db
paragraph.content: on their detention in any proceedings under the Fugitive Offenders Ordinance (Cap. 503); (23 of 1997 s. 28)

paragraph.name: ea
paragraph.content: on their detention by virtue of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115); (55 of 1971 s. 66)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: whose cases have been referred back to a magistrate under the provisions of sections 10 and 11 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221), while the cases are being so dealt with;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: debtors;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: on their commitment under section 27 or 29 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: who have been declared by any enactment in force in Hong Kong to be or are to be treated as prisoners awaiting trial. (L.N. 213 of 1986)

subsection.content: Where any of the circumstances stated in subrule (1) becomes applicable to a person who is already a convicted prisoner, rules 204 and 206 shall apply to him as if he were a prisoner awaiting trial. (L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s189
section.heading: Bath
section.content: A prisoner awaiting trial shall not be required to take a bath on reception, if, on the application of the prisoner, the Superintendent decides that it is unnecessary, or the Medical Officer states that it is for medical reasons inadvisable.

section.name: s190
section.heading: Segregation
section.content: Prisoners awaiting trial shall be kept apart from convicted prisoners and shall not be allowed to associate with them at any time.

section.name: s191
section.heading: Power of Superintendent to modify routine
section.content: The Superintendent may modify the routine of the prison in regard to any class of prisoners awaiting trial, so far as to dispense with any practice which, in the Superintendent’s opinion, is clearly unnecessary in the case of that particular class of prisoners.

section.name: s198
section.heading: Prohibition of sale
section.content: Every prisoner awaiting trial shall not sell or transfer to any other person any article whatsoever allowed to be introduced into the prison for his own use.

section.name: s199
section.heading: Direction as to hair cutting
section.content: The hair of every prisoner awaiting trial may be cut but not in such a manner as may alter his appearance.

section.name: s200
section.heading: Duty as to cleanliness of room, etc.
section.leadIn: Every prisoner awaiting trial shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make his bed and clean the room, toilet and surrounds, and yard in his occupation every morning;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: keep clean and in good order the furniture, utensils, clothing and bedding appropriated for his use.

section.name: s201
section.heading: Option of employment
section.content: Every prisoner awaiting trial shall have the option of employment in the service or industries of the prison at his election. In the event of a prisoner electing to be so employed he shall receive payment in accordance with rates to be fixed by the Commissioner.

section.name: s202
section.heading: Supply of means of occupation
section.leadIn: The Superintendent must supply to any prisoner awaiting trial, at the prisoner’s own expense, newspapers or other means of occupation that are not, in the opinion of the Superintendent, of an objectionable nature, so long as the Superintendent has reasonable grounds to believe that the supply will not bring about one or more of the following effects—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being contrary to the interests of national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: tending to cause the commission of any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: posing a threat to any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posing a threat to the security, good order and discipline of the prison.

subsection.content: Subject to these rules, a prisoner awaiting trial must not receive any visit from any person who has not been authorized under subrule (2).
The Commissioner may authorize any person whom the Commissioner considers appropriate for the purposes of subrule (1).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the restrictions and conditions mentioned in subrule (4), a prisoner awaiting trial may receive a visit from any person for one or both of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enabling the prisoner to maintain connections with his or her family or with society;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing moral support or material support to the prisoner.

subsection.leadIn: The restrictions and conditions are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prisoner must consent to receiving the visit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the visit must not be made otherwise than on the date and at the time specified by the Superintendent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: every prisoner awaiting trial must not receive the visit more than once per day;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the visit must be made by not more than 2 visitors on each occasion;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the visit is limited to 15 minutes on each occasion;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: at least 1 officer of the Correctional Services Department must be present during the visit; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a person who wishes to make the visit must produce the person’s proof of identity (as defined by section 17B(1) of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115)) in advance to an officer of the Correctional Services Department for inspection, and provide the person’s name, address, the relationship to the prisoner, and other personal data that the Superintendent reasonably considers to be necessary for the purposes of this rule, to the officer for record purposes.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subrule (3), the Superintendent may, for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subrule (6)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the visit—

subparagraph.content: vary one or more of the restrictions or conditions mentioned in subrule (4); or
impose any other restrictions or conditions; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prohibit the visit.

subsection.leadIn: The purposes are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safeguarding national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: preventing or detecting any criminal offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: safeguarding any individual’s personal safety;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: maintaining the security, good order and discipline of the prison.

section.name: s204
section.heading: Private medical adviser
section.content: Subject to rule 204A, every prisoner awaiting trial may, for the purpose of the prisoner’s defence, receive a visit from a registered medical practitioner selected by the prisoner, or by a person who may act on the prisoner’s behalf, under the same conditions as applicable to a visit by a barrister or solicitor.

section.name: s204A
section.heading: Prisoners awaiting trial may be restricted from receiving visits from particular registered medical practitioners in certain circumstances

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a prisoner awaiting trial, or a person who may act on the prisoner’s behalf, requests to receive a visit from a particular registered medical practitioner under rule 204; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prisoner awaiting trial is receiving a visit from a particular registered medical practitioner under that rule.

subsection.content: A specified officer may apply to a magistrate in accordance with subrule (3) for the issue of a warrant by the magistrate under subrule (5) in relation to the prisoner.
The application must be supported by information on oath and be made ex parte to a magistrate by a specified officer.

However, if the magistrate considers, in the circumstances of the case, that it is in the interests of justice for the proceedings relating to the application to be held inter partes, the magistrate may direct the proceedings to be so held.

subsection.leadIn: If the magistrate hearing the application is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the circumstances mentioned in subrule (6) exist, the magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing an officer of the Correctional Services Department to impose the following restrictions on the prisoner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prisoner must not, within the period specified in the warrant, receive any visit from the medical practitioner; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prisoner may, under these rules, receive a visit from any other registered medical practitioner selected by the prisoner, or by a person who may act on the prisoner’s behalf.

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the prisoner’s receiving of a visit from the medical practitioner will—

subparagraph.content: endanger national security; or
cause bodily harm to any person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prisoner has benefited from any criminal offence committed or allegedly committed by him or her, and the prisoner’s receiving of a visit from the medical practitioner will hinder the recovery of the benefit unless the authorization is given; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the prisoner’s receiving of a visit from the medical practitioner will pervert or obstruct the course of justice unless the authorization is given.

subsection.leadIn: If an application is made under subrule (2), then before the magistrate decides the application, the prisoner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not receive any visit from the medical practitioner; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, under these rules, receive a visit from any other registered medical practitioner selected by the prisoner, or by a person who may act on the prisoner’s behalf.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, for the purposes of this rule, authorize any officer of the Correctional Services Department (other than an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Superintendent).

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Superintendent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department authorized under subrule (8).

subsection.content: If, after the issue of a warrant under rule 204A(5), a specified officer (as defined by rule 204A(9)) no longer has reasonable grounds to believe that the circumstances mentioned in rule 204A(6) exist, an officer of the Correctional Services Department must immediately cease to impose on the prisoner the restrictions under rule 204A(5).
If a warrant is issued under rule 204A(5) in relation to a prisoner awaiting trial, the prisoner may apply to a magistrate to vary or revoke the warrant.
An application made under rule 204A(2) or subrule (2) must be heard in a closed court.
Despite subrule (3), the magistrate hearing the application may, either on the magistrate’s own motion or on application by any party to the hearing, order the application to be heard in open court.

However, the magistrate concerned may only make an order under subrule (4) on being satisfied that doing so is necessary in the interests of justice and would not be contrary to the interests of national security.

Every prisoner awaiting trial may send and receive letters at all reasonable times and shall be furnished by the Superintendent with a reasonable amount of paper and other writing materials for communication or for preparing the defence.

Subject to rule 52C, if a prisoner awaiting trial prepares confidential written communication as instructions to the prisoner’s barrister or solicitor, and the barrister or solicitor or a person who assists the barrister or solicitor’s performance of his or her functions as a barrister or solicitor (assistant) visits the prisoner under rule 52, the communication may be delivered by the prisoner personally to the barrister, solicitor or assistant without previously being read by an officer of the prisons.

subsection.leadIn: This rule does not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: rule 47 (except rule 47(2) and (3)); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rules 47A and 47B. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

section.name: s207
section.heading: Attendance at religious services
section.content: It shall not be compulsory for any prisoner awaiting trial to attend any religious service but he shall be ordinarily entitled to attend religious services of his religion conducted in the prison in which he is confined.

section.name: s208
section.heading: Power of visiting justices and Superintendent to grant and withdraw facilities

subsection.content: The visiting justices or the Superintendent, before granting any permission which by these rules they are authorized or required to grant, shall satisfy themselves that it can be granted without interfering with the security, good order and government of the prison.

If there is any abuse of the facilities so granted, the visiting justices shall have power to suspend or withdraw such permission, and the Superintendent may withdraw it if granted by himself, or suspend it if granted by the visiting justices, if the case is urgent, provided he reports the case as soon as possible to the visiting justices.

section.name: s210
section.heading: Appellants
section.leadIn: The following rules apply to persons (hereinafter referred to as appellants) committed to prison for safe custody—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who have lodged an appeal to which section 105 or 113 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) applies and have obtained a stay of execution or sentence under the provisions of section 118 thereof; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who have been committed under section 81(3)(b) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: who, as appellants, have not been admitted to bail under section 83R of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221).

section.name: s211
section.heading: Option of employment
section.content: Every appellant shall have the option of employment in the service or industries of the prison at his election. In the event of an appellant electing to be so employed he shall receive payment in accordance with rates to be fixed by the Commissioner.

section.name: s212
section.heading: Earnings for work done
section.content: If an appellant is ordered by a judge to be released otherwise than on bail pending the hearing of his appeal, payment of all sums of money earned by him under the provisions of rule 211 shall be paid to him.

section.name: s213
section.heading: Private medical adviser
section.content: Subject to rule 213A, every appellant may, for the purpose of the appellant’s appeal, receive a visit from a registered medical practitioner selected by the appellant, or by a person who may act on the appellant’s behalf, under the same conditions as applicable to a visit by a barrister or solicitor.

section.name: s213A
section.heading: Appellants may be restricted from receiving visits from particular registered medical practitioners in certain circumstances

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appellant, or a person who may act on the appellant’s behalf, requests to receive a visit from a particular registered medical practitioner under rule 213; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an appellant is receiving a visit from a particular registered medical practitioner under that rule.

subsection.content: A specified officer may apply to a magistrate in accordance with subrule (3) for the issue of a warrant by the magistrate under subrule (5) in relation to the appellant.
The application must be supported by information on oath and be made ex parte to a magistrate by a specified officer.

However, if the magistrate considers, in the circumstances of the case, that it is in the interests of justice for the proceedings relating to the application to be held inter partes, the magistrate may direct the proceedings to be so held.

subsection.leadIn: If the magistrate hearing the application is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the circumstances mentioned in subrule (6) exist, the magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing an officer of the Correctional Services Department to impose the following restrictions on the appellant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appellant must not, within the period specified in the warrant, receive any visit from the medical practitioner; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the appellant may, under these rules, receive a visit from any other registered medical practitioner selected by the appellant, or by a person who may act on the appellant’s behalf.

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the appellant’s receiving of a visit from the medical practitioner will—

subparagraph.content: endanger national security; or
cause bodily harm to any person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the appellant has benefited from any criminal offence committed or allegedly committed by him or her, and the appellant’s receiving of a visit from the medical practitioner will hinder the recovery of the benefit unless the authorization is given; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the appellant’s receiving of a visit from the medical practitioner will pervert or obstruct the course of justice unless the authorization is given.

subsection.leadIn: If an application is made under subrule (2), then before the magistrate decides the application, the appellant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not receive any visit from the medical practitioner; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, under these rules, receive a visit from any other registered medical practitioner selected by the appellant, or by a person who may act on the appellant’s behalf.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, for the purposes of this rule, authorize any officer of the Correctional Services Department (other than an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Superintendent).

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department not below the rank of Superintendent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department authorized under subrule (8).

subsection.content: If, after the issue of a warrant under rule 213A(5), a specified officer (as defined by rule 213A(9)) no longer has reasonable grounds to believe that the circumstances mentioned in rule 213A(6) exist, an officer of the Correctional Services Department must immediately cease to impose on the appellant the restrictions under rule 213A(5).
If a warrant is issued under rule 213A(5) in relation to an appellant, the appellant may apply to a magistrate to vary or revoke the warrant.
An application made under rule 213A(2) or subrule (2) must be heard in a closed court.
Despite subrule (3), the magistrate hearing the application may, either on the magistrate’s own motion or on application by any party to the hearing, order the application to be heard in open court.

However, the magistrate concerned may only make an order under subrule (4) on being satisfied that doing so is necessary in the interests of justice and would not be contrary to the interests of national security.

Every appellant may send and receive letters at all reasonable times and shall be furnished by the Superintendent with a reasonable amount of paper and other writing materials for communication or for preparing the appeal.

Subject to rule 52C, if an appellant prepares confidential written communication as instructions to the appellant’s barrister or solicitor, and the barrister or solicitor or a person who assists the barrister or solicitor’s performance of his or her functions as a barrister or solicitor (assistant) visits the appellant under rule 52, the communication may be delivered by the appellant personally to the barrister, solicitor or assistant without previously being read by an officer. (31 of 1983 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: This rule does not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: rule 47 (except rule 47(2) and (3)); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rules 47A and 47B. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

section.name: s215
section.heading: Application of rules as to privileges and remission of sentence

subsection.content: A prisoner committed for contempt, or for failing to do or abstain from doing anything required to be done or left undone, shall be subject to the special rules under this Part that apply to prisoners awaiting trial.

A prisoner detained in a prison for a stated term on committal for contempt, or for failing to do or abstain from doing anything required to be done or left undone, shall, for the purpose of rule 69, be treated as serving a sentence of imprisonment for the stated term.

subsection.leadIn: Two visiting justices shall, in company if possible, visit— (L.N. 270 of 2000)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each prison at least once a fortnight;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each hostel at least once a month,

subsection.continued: and on such other days as they may be required. (44 of 1987 s. 3)

subsection.content: The names of the visiting justices shall be furnished by the Chief Secretary for Administration to the Commissioner and the prisons and hostels shall be open to them at all reasonable times during their tour of duty. (44 of 1987 s. 3; L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s223
section.heading: Duty to record recommendations
section.content: Visiting justices shall at the termination of every visit and before they leave a prison or hostel record their recommendations in a book provided for the purpose.

section.name: s224
section.heading: Interest in contracts
section.content: Visiting justices shall not have any interest in any contract made in respect of any prisons or hostels.

section.name: s225
section.heading: Co-operation with Commissioner
section.text: Visiting justices shall co-operate with the Commissioner in promoting the efficiency of the service and shall make inquiry into any matter especially referred to them by the Chief Executive.

subsection.content: Visiting justices shall ensure that all abuses in connexion with the prison or hostel which come to their knowledge are brought to the notice of the Commissioner immediately.

They shall enter in a book provided for the purpose any statement in respect of abuses brought to their notice with any suggestions or remarks which they may wish to bring to the notice of the Chief Executive as to the state and discipline of the prison or hostel. (15 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s227
section.heading: Duty to supply information
section.text: Visiting justices shall furnish such information with respect to the offences reported to them as may be required by the Chief Executive from time to time.

subsection.content: Visiting justices shall hear and investigate any complaint which any prisoner or resident of a hostel may desire to make to them.
They shall pay special attention to prisoners, or residents of hostels, in hospital and prisoners in separate confinement. (L.N. 65 of 1969)

section.name: s229
section.heading: Duty to report injuries caused by discipline or treatment
section.text: Visiting justices shall attend to all reports received by them as to the mind or body of any prisoner or resident of a hostel being likely to be injured by discipline or treatment to which he is subjected, and shall communicate their opinion to the Chief Executive.

section.name: s230
section.heading: Duty as to prisoners’ diets
section.content: Visiting justices shall inspect the diets of the prisoners or residents of the hostels, and if they consider that the food supplied does not conform to the approved diet scale under which it is supplied, they shall report the circumstances to the Commissioner, and make a note of such circumstances in a book provided for the purpose, and the Superintendent shall thereupon take such steps as may be immediately necessary to provide the prisoners or residents of the hostels with suitable food.

section.name: s231
section.heading: Power to inspect books
section.content: Visiting justices may inspect any of the books of the prison or hostel.

section.name: s232
section.heading: Duty to advise on employment and occupation
section.content: Visiting justices shall assist the Commissioner with advice and suggestions as to the industrial employment and occupation of prisoners and residents of hostels with particular relation to their employment on discharge.

section.name: s233
section.heading: Power to organize lectures and addresses
section.content: Visiting justices may, subject to the approval of the Commissioner, organize lectures and addresses in the prison or hostel, provided they in the case of lectures and addresses in the prison do not interfere with the necessities of prison discipline, and are directed to the moral improvement of the prisoners.

section.name: s234
section.heading: Duty to inquire and report on state of prison buildings
section.content: Visiting justices shall inquire into the state of the prison or hostel buildings, and report to the Chief Executive with respect to any repairs or additions which may appear to them to be necessary.

section.name: s235
section.heading: Duty to discharge other duties assigned by the Chief Executive
section.text: Visiting justices shall also discharge such other duties as may be assigned to them by the Chief Executive.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, from time to time, appoint any person interested in the welfare, reform and after-care of prisoners to be a prison visitor.
A prison visitor shall conform to these rules and be subject to the orders of the Superintendent.
Access to any prisoner by a prison visitor shall be arranged at the discretion of the Superintendent.
A prisoner shall have the right to decline to be visited by a particular visitor.
A prison visitor shall inform the Superintendent when he decides to discontinue visiting a particular prisoner.
A prison visitor shall, as soon as conveniently possible, inform the Superintendent of any abuse, unlawful activity or impropriety in the prison which may come to his knowledge.
A prison visitor shall not make public or use to his own benefit any knowledge which he may gain through his appointment as a prison visitor.

subsection.leadIn: A prison visitor shall not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carry in or out of the prison any article or document or transmit any message for any prisoner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: discuss a prisoner’s conviction or sentence or any other official matter with a prisoner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: communicate with a prisoner’s family or friends,

subsection.continued: except with the prior consent of the Superintendent.

section.name: s237
section.heading: Use of force
section.content: No officer of the Correctional Services Department may use unnecessary force in performing a function as such an officer.

section.name: s238
section.heading: Occasions when arms may be used

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a prisoner escapes or attempts to escape, or a person assists a prisoner in escaping;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person participates in or facilitates collective disturbance of prisoners;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person attempts to force or break open the outside door, gate or enclosure wall of a prison;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a prisoner uses, or a person and a prisoner jointly use, violence to another person; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person uses violence to an officer of the Correctional Services Department performing a function as such an officer, or to a prisoner.

subsection.content: An officer of the Correctional Services Department may, in so far as it is reasonably necessary, stop any person (subject person), by the use of arms, from doing an act mentioned in subrule (1).

However, if the act is one mentioned in subrule (1)(d) or (e), an officer of the Correctional Services Department may so use arms only if the officer has reasonable grounds to believe that a person to whom the violence is used is in danger of life, or limb, or that other grievous harm is likely to be caused to the person.

Before using arms against the subject person under subrule (2), the officer must warn the subject person that the officer is about to fire on the subject person, unless it is not reasonably practicable in the circumstances.

section.name: s238AA
section.heading: Offence of resisting or obstructing officer in performing certain functions

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, resists or obstructs an officer of the Correctional Services Department in the performance of a function as such an officer commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In criminal proceedings for an offence under subrule (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the burden of establishing that a person has a reasonable excuse mentioned in that subrule lies on the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person is taken to have established the reasonable excuse if—

subparagraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to the reasonable excuse; and
the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

subsection.content: If an officer of the Correctional Services Department reasonably suspects that a person (subject person) has committed an offence under rule 238AA(1), or has committed any criminal offence for doing an act mentioned in rule 238(1), the officer may arrest the subject person without warrant.

After an officer of the Correctional Services Department arrests a subject person under subrule (1), the officer must as soon as reasonably practicable hand the subject person over to the custody of a police officer to be dealt with in accordance with the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232).

If the subject person forcibly resists or attempts to evade arrest under subrule (1), an officer of the Correctional Services Department may effect the arrest by the use of force that is reasonably necessary.

An officer of the Correctional Services Department is not civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by the officer in good faith in performing, or purportedly performing, a function as such an officer.
Subrule (1) does not affect any liability of the Government for the act or omission of any officer of the Correctional Services Department.

part.name: P5
part.heading: Disciplinary Provisions Applicable to All Officers and Other Persons Employed in Prisons

section.name: s238A
section.heading: Interpretation of this Part
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: defence representative (辯護代表) means a person specified in rule 245A(1)(a) or (b) who represents an accused at a hearing;
hearing (聆訊) means a hearing conducted in respect of a disciplinary offence. (L.N. 174 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: Any officer of the Correctional Services Department or other person employed in the prisons commits a disciplinary offence who— (L.N. 65 of 1969; L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: is insubordinate towards any officer in the service of the Correctional Services Department whose orders it is for the time being his duty to obey; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: neglects, or without good and sufficient cause fails to do, promptly and diligently, anything which it is his duty to do; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by carelessness or neglect in the performance of his duty contributes to the occurrence of any loss, damage or injury to any person or property;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: knowingly makes any false, misleading, or inaccurate statement in connexion with his duty either verbally, or in any official document or book, or signs any such statement, or with intent to deceive, destroys or mutilates any such document or book, or erases any entry therein;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: fails to account for, or to make a prompt and true return of, any money or property for which he is responsible whether in connexion with his duties as an officer of the Correctional Services Department or other person employed in the prisons or with any club or fund connected with the prison or the staff; (L.N. 30 of 1982; 31 of 1983 s. 8)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: improperly uses his position as an officer of the Correctional Services Department or other person employed in the prisons to his personal advantage; (L.N. 30 of 1982)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: without proper authority—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: carries out any pecuniary or business transaction with or on behalf of any prisoner or ex-prisoner, or with a relative or friend of any prisoner or ex-prisoner;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: brings in or carries out, or attempts to bring in or carry out, or knowingly allows to be brought in or carried out, to or for any prisoner any article whatsoever;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: solicits or accepts any advantage from any prisoner or ex-prisoner, or from a friend or relative of any prisoner or ex-prisoner; (L.N. 353 of 1981)

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: communicates with a prisoner for an improper purpose;

subparagraph.name: iii
iv

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: deliberately acts in a manner calculated to provoke a prisoner;

paragraph.name: j
k
paragraph.leadIn: without proper authority or reasonable excuse—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: absents himself from the prison, or from any parade, or place of duty;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: arrives late for any duty or parade;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: wilfully or negligently damages or loses any article of clothing, or personal equipment with which he has been provided, or entrusted, or fails to take proper care thereof;

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: when on duty, or called upon for duty, is unfit for duty by reason of alcoholic drink or of drugs taken otherwise than under medical direction; (L.N. 154 of 1977)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: while on or off duty acts in a disorderly manner, or in any manner prejudicial to discipline, or likely to bring discredit on the service; (31 of 1983 s. 8)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: smokes, or drinks intoxicating liquor either within the prison walls (except under such restrictions as to time and place as may be prescribed), or while on duty in a court of law, or when in charge of prisoners outside the prison;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: borrows money from an officer subordinate or junior in rank, or lends money to his superior officer, or stands surety for a brother officer in raising a loan;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: contravenes any of these rules or commits any breach of duty; (L.N. 65 of 1969)

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.content: is guilty of anything, whether by reason of contravention of government regulations or otherwise, which amounts to misconduct in a public officer; (L.N. 154 of 1977; 15 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: r
paragraph.content: having been interdicted under the Ordinance, does not immediately give up his keys and accoutrements.

def.name: Advantage
def.leadIn: In this rule advantage (利益) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any gift, loan, fee, reward or commission consisting of money or of any valuable security or of other property or interest in property of any description;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any office, employment or contract;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: any other service, or favour (other than entertainment), including protection from any penalty or disability incurred or apprehended or from any action or proceedings of a disciplinary, civil or criminal nature, whether or not already instituted;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: any offer, undertaking or promise, whether conditional or unconditional, of any advantage within the meaning of any of the preceding paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e). (L.N. 353 of 1981)

division.name: D3
division.heading: Rules of Procedure and Disciplinary Awards

subsection.content: A charge against an accused must be entered on a charge sheet as soon as practicable after consideration by an officer, not being below the rank of Chief Officer, of the report upon which the charge is based. (G.N.A. 68 of 1961; L.N. 44 of 1966; L.N. 65 of 1969; L.N. 154 of 1977)

The disciplinary offence alleged must be specifically stated in the charge sheet which must also contain the particulars that leave the accused under no misapprehension as to the charge. (L.N. 60 of 2012 and L.N. 150 of 2014)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: The charge sheet together with a list of witnesses whom it is proposed to call and any written statements which it is proposed to adduce in support of the charge must be served on the accused at the earliest possible moment.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: The accused must be allowed a reasonable opportunity to make copies of all documents for the purposes of the defence, and must, if the accused so requests, be given copies of them. (L.N. 60 of 2012 and L.N. 150 of 2014)

section.name: s243A
section.heading: Appointment of prosecutor
section.content: The Commissioner must appoint a prosecutor for the purposes of the proceedings against an accused under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: The accused must, as soon as possible, and in any case not later than 24 hours after receipt of the charge sheet—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state in writing on the charge sheet his or her reply to the charge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: set out on a list the names of the witnesses the accused wishes to call; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: return the charge sheet to a senior officer specified for the purpose of this rule on the charge sheet.

subsection.content: The senior officer must transmit the charge sheet, list of witnesses and all written statements to the prosecutor.

section.name: s245
section.heading: Power of Superintendent to hear charges

subsection.content: Subrule (2) or (3) applies if on consideration of the report on which the charge is based and the written statements (if any), the Superintendent considers that the charge is within his or her competence, and that, if it is admitted or found proved, the Superintendent’s powers of punishment are sufficient.

subsection.leadIn: If the accused admits the charge, the Superintendent must, after hearing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the accused or the defence representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any witness called by the accused for the purpose of extenuation or explanation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other witnesses whom the Superintendent or the prosecutor may consider desirable to call,

subsection.continued: either caution the accused, or make a disciplinary award within the Superintendent’s powers.

subsection.leadIn: If the accused denies the charge, the Superintendent must, at the earliest possible moment, arrange for the attendance of all necessary witnesses and must, after hearing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all the evidence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any explanation given by the accused or the defence representative,

subsection.continued: either dismiss the charge or, if the Superintendent finds the charge proved, administer a caution or make a disciplinary award within the Superintendent’s powers.

subsection.content: If the Superintendent, after hearing all of the evidence on a charge, comes to the conclusion that the charge is proved but that the case should be referred to the Commissioner, the Superintendent must so refer the case and immediately inform the accused accordingly.

If the accused is informed by the Superintendent that the case has been referred to the Commissioner under subrule (4), the accused may, within 14 days after being so informed or within any further period that the Commissioner may allow, make representations in writing to the Commissioner.

If on consideration of the report on which the charge is based and the written statements (if any), the Superintendent considers that the charge is not within his or her competence or that, although it is within his or her competence, his or her powers of punishment would be insufficient if the charge were admitted or found proved, the Superintendent must refer the case to the Commissioner and must so inform the accused.
The Commissioner may either deal with the case in person or direct the Deputy Commissioner to hear the charge and must so inform the accused.

subsection.leadIn: An accused may be represented at a hearing by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (subject to the Commissioner’s approval) a barrister or solicitor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person of the accused’s choice who is approved by the Commissioner for the purpose,

subsection.continued: and the person specified in paragraph (a) or (b) may conduct the defence on the accused’s behalf.

subsection.content: If the Commissioner gives approval under subrule (1)(a), the accused may be represented at the hearing by a barrister or solicitor of the accused’s choice.
Despite subrule (1), the accused must attend the hearing in person.
If the accused is represented at the hearing by a barrister or solicitor, the person hearing the charge and the prosecutor may separately be assisted by a barrister or solicitor at the hearing.
An accused and the defence representative must be allowed to hear all of the evidence adduced at a hearing.

The prosecutor or any barrister or solicitor assisting the prosecutor may examine and re-examine any witness giving evidence against the accused, and may cross-examine any witness called by the accused.
The accused or the defence representative may cross-examine any witness giving evidence against the accused, and may examine and re-examine any witness called by the accused.

subsection.leadIn: The person hearing a charge may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: call witnesses; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ask any witness any question,

subsection.continued: that the person considers may assist him or her in determining the case.

section.name: s246A
section.heading: Proceedings in accused’s absence
